column10: 1) Why is 6 months postdoc experiance required? Seems overly restrictive 2) It means "at least 6 months". Presumably they don't want to hire anyone who's ABD, and so wrote the ad so as to rule out ABD candidates. 3) ecoevojobs.net commenters reading a broad ad with few details: "Boo! Be specific!" ecoevojobs.net commenters reading a specific, detailed ad: "Boo! Overly restrictive!" 4) The specifics people want are about job details, not extra arbitrary restrictions on eligibility. 5) Requiring postdoc experience is extremely normal for a TT search in the sciences. Hardly an arbitrary restriction. x6 6) You really think 0 vs 6 months of postdoc experience makes any tangible difference in a candidate's ability to do this job? Most ads say postdoc experience preferred which at least leaves room for flexibility. 7) @6 yes it does! It means you have now graduated and are able to reach out to potential collaborators, think of a project, perhaps discuss funding related things, and have started to understand how things work on the other side of the wall. If you are asking this question... perhaps you need some more months as postdoc to asnwer it by yourself. 6) Lol 7, I've got plenty of postdoc and PI experience. Requiring a completed PhD is one thing. 6 months into a postdoc you have probably just finished actually getting moved and figuring out what your new lab even does. 7) Many comments on this board imply that the people who wrote the ad are incompetent at their jobs; this comment thread is just one example of many. I would be genuinely curious to hear comments from people who ended up taking jobs for which there are comments on this board implying that that the members of the hiring department are incompetent. Did they actually turn out to be incompetent once you showed up on campus and started working with them? 8) If you see something oddly specific in a job ad it's almost always either a compromise or some weird HR restriction. Don't overthink it. If the job ad said "PhD completed" people would waffle about whether that meant "graduated" versus "defended." Being partway into a postdoc means you've secured said postdoc, which is in and of itself representative of something useful. 9) Many times language in the job ad is polished by HR. So... instead of asking you must have a completed PhD by the time of hire, HR may suggest, just request a postdoc... that way you dont have to dsicriminate through applicants and end up offering the job to someone that will have to wait another 6 months to graduate. People in this forum overthink things too much... and complain for no reason. The other day someone was complaining about a job in THE FRENCH part of Canada requiring proficience in French. LOL. x3 10) these phd hires in the US are out of hand anyways... i think all permant positions should require a 2 year postdoc

column10: 1) Are these two positions at Wilfrid Laurier part of a cluster hire? Or are they unrelated?. 2) Curious if anyone has insights into this department / university for research? 3) Unlike the US funding isn't biased in distribution between schools so a good proposal get money wherever it's from. That said this school isn't known for BIOL and currently ranks 12/15 in its category: https://macleans.ca/education/university-rankings/canadas-best-comprehensive-universities-for-2026/ In Canada and CDN applications, it's much more important to consider city/province than school/ranking. 4) i believe these are part of a cluster hire. teaching intensive school. 5) This has oddly specific job requirements. Can a search committee member weigh in here?

column10: 1) Are these two positions at Wilfrid Laurier part of a cluster hire? Or are they unrelated? 2) i believe these are part of a cluster hire. teaching intensive school. 3) Looking into the job, it seems like there is a strong preference for Canadian applicants. Also looking into the department, it seems very much filled with individuals with a Canadian history (gauging by edu and research posts). Doing a bit of digging, this prefence seems based in Canadian law. As a non-Canadian and non-permanent resident applicant, is it really worth applying? Do non-Canadian applicants ever outperform the preference? 4) Every job in Canada has this preference. Non-Canadians can overcome it if the committee ranks no Canadians as qualified at the campus interview. Still worth applying though your chances are definitely lower. 5) Canadian prof here; I was not a Canadian when I was hired. What 4 said is correct. 6) In addition to be qualified myself, I'd also need Canadian candicates to be unqualified? That sounds like a matter of luck for foreigner/exogenous people. 5) nothing is coincidental 7) Like any position, "reasons" to disqualify the Canadian citizen can also be created 8) Yeah typically the committee would have to have a strong preference for non-can and rank all finalist canadians as not acceptable. They can justify that however they want, but the risk is that if top choice declines you can't go back to the rest of the candidates. I don't know this department but I would expect the preference is harder to overcome at a more teaching focused school.

column10: 1) Hull lecturer here (but not on the selection panel). Please note that a 'Lecturer' in the UK is a permanent PI position, equivalent to Assistant Professor. This job involves teaching at undergrad and masters level, and research in themes such as "oceanography, polar ecology, fisheries science, marine benthic ecology, intertidal ecology, conservation and habitat restoration, marine policy and social science, GIS and spatial data, microplastics, blue carbon and offshore wind. Our research is conducted in collaboration with external bodies, including industry and governmental agencies". Hull and the surrounding area is very affordable to live, close to national parks and offering a vibrant social and live music scene.  2) "one of the great universities: Oxford, Cambridge, Hull" (1 again) "Oxford's a complete dump!" 3) Is a £50k salary enough to live well? 4) @ 3) probably enough for Hull, which has much lower CoL than the Southeast of England 5) £50k ~ $67k. You won't be wealthy but you'll be relatively comfortable. 1) I am on this payband at Hull, and it's very liveable. 5) anyone else have trouble with getting the apply link to work? It directs me to a 'page not found'

column10: 1) Note that this is 3x Lectureship positions being recruited. 2) No information on what to upload (e.g., research statement, teaching statement, etc). Anyone have an idea? x2 3) A lot of UK jobs are just a CV + cover letter. Looks like that's the case here. 4) I attached my research and teaching statements as "additional documents" 5) Just FYI, British universities are generally super concerned with fair play, so I'm guessing HR will remove additional statements added as additional documents. Don't assume those will get through to the committee (make sure research/teaching basics are in your cover letter). 6) I have applied there in the past and inquired  then - they wanted both research and teaching statement and suggested to combine it into a single PDF together with the CV (this was one year ago). 7) Looks like they got questions and updated the page to say "Documents required for application are your CV and a cover letter. Within the CV please include a research and teaching statement. " 8) Just came to say I emailed them about it and got the same response as 7, glad they updated it. 9) Staff member here, I have confirmed that the expectations is exactly as outlined in 7, they have apparently updated the advert. Best of luck!

column10: sounds like a postdoc, 1) "purpose-driven science" -what the hail is this? name one instituion that is not purpose-driven. This sounds like american fluff for nothing 2) Current postdoc here and no, these Research Associate positions are not postdocs! They function a bit differently, pay better, and (from what I have seen, I don't know what the exact situation with this one is obviously) tend to be/ tend to lead to more permanent postitions than a postdoc where the expectation is that you move on at the end of the term. 3) Sounds like a cool gig!  4) @2 it's one year, extendable to three, you're doing mostly research and you have a supervisor. What makes this different from a postdoc except the salary? 5) Former CLO person here. Research Associate positions are essentially PI positions – you run your own research program, but without some of the tedium and BS that comes from running your own lab (sort of unfortunate that the title doesn't properly convey the status). You're a bit buffered by Cornell, pretty cushy in that way. You won't get your own physical lab space, but you have access to many great shared spaces. Expectations are similar to what they are for faculty at many research-intensive institutions. Cornell always offers "one year, renewable" contracts, so this isn't unusual. Check the list of current Research Associates on their website...these folks are doing stellar work. No teaching either. A dream position for the right person. 6) also former recent CLO person. Research associate is a catchall title that can be a position like 5 describes (rare) but can be much more like a postdoc contract that expires. Still looks like a nice position but I wouldn't count on it being long term or would at least ask a lot of questions. 7) Basically it is a non-tenure track research professor. X2 8) Cornell person here. RA roles function more like higher-paid postdocs as Cornell has tightened PI eligibility. I’d clarify whether this position includes PI status. 9) Does this position require 100k USD payment for people from outside the US? 10) Not associated with Cornell in any way. But generally speaking, if you are a non-US citizen currently in the US and if Cornell is willing to sponsor H1-Bs, the 100k fee most likely won't apply. If you are a non-US citizen currently not living in the US, it most likely will apply. They probably won't proceed with a H1-B process in such a scenario anyway.

column10: We are interested in hiring interdisciplinary scientists whose research addresses fundamental and applied questions in the coastal, near-shore marine, and oceanographic sciences. We invite qualified candidates within these broad disciplines whose research uses observational, modelling, theoretical, and/or experimental approaches to apply for three (3) open positions based at the DeFelice Marine Center in Cocodrie, Louisiana. [link updated -AP] 2) Just so anyone potentially interested is aware, the resources are tough to get (unless you are really interested in ship time) and the closest place to live is Chauvin (not Cocodrie where LUMCON is) so your shortest possible commute is 20-30 minutes. 3) What is ship time? 4) I assume time on a research ship. 5) @2 I'm not sure what you mean by "the resources are tough to get" but I'm happy to answer specific questions anyone has! 6) @5, or others, what is the expected pay range? What internal funding opportunities exists for hiring graduate students through the member universities? Is there no teaching load? Are there options to teach? What is the vibe like out there - does it feel quiet and remote or is it busy and active?(one isn't inherently better than the other, just curious). 7) @6 - pay is generous and fair, I'm not entirely sure what exactly it would be but, its a 9 month appointment, and I would expect the 9 month salary to be low to mid $80K. There are no established internal funding mechanisms for graduate students, they all must be grant supported or you can co-advise with a faculty member at a consortium university that has access to TAships. You are expected to co-teach 1 semester course a year and contribute to the internship programs we provide for undergraduates over the summer. There are more opportunities to teach if you persue them. The vibe is quiet and remote during the typical academic year and busy and active during the summer - somewhat of the reverse of "typical" academic appointments.

column10: Initial appointment 2 years as Lecturer, with potential to convert to tenure-track.2) must not require visa sponsorship. 3) booo! x6 4) why is the pay not included in the ad? 5) This is a SUNY thing - state orgs are not required to post salary (though many ads do). YOu can look up assistant prof salaries in the department (they are all public). Also, this program is mean to recruit folks into TT, so the intention really is to have people move into a permanent position after the first two years (not just a vague possibility like with some VAPs) 6) I can't understand why universities are still balking at the prospect of sponsoring a visa in cases where the $100k fee does not apply. It has been several months since this was clarified. 7) @5 so since this is intially a lecturer position, you would be looking up the salaries of lecturers, not assistant professor. 8) Is this for a more seasoned postdoc, or does a fresh PhD stand a chance? 5) @7 or maybe try to check the current salaries of existing prodig+ fellows (there's a bunch throughout the SUNY system), @8 I can't comment on this specific search, but the whole point of the program is to help folks build up their CV to be competititve for a faculty position, so I can't imagine they'd automatically exclude people earlier in their career.... 6) the latest PRODiG hires in a dif dept were early career/ recently finished PhD students. Yes, the salary is similar to "Lecturer" in the SUNY system and SUNY employee salaries are public 7) No visa sponsorship? Given the absolutely massive surge of US applications into EU positions, the lack of reciprocity on that one does sting a bit. 9) ironic that this was designed to "promote diversity, equity, and inclusion" and "open to all candidates regardless of national origin" when it doesn't even sponsor a visa--how does that even make any sense x2 10) This job says preferences to Pell grant recipients or first gen students; anyone know the best way to indicate you were part of those groups? Part of diversity statement or cover letter? 11) It it were me I'd put it in both and bold that text. Gotta take every opportunity you get...

column10: 1) "Would be an advantage if you have: a) established an independent research group. b) published work in the most prominent scientific journals such as Science, Nature, Cell and PNAS. c) been awarded larger research grants in competition, such as a starting grant d) your PhD and postdoctoral experience from an internationally leading university/research institute." 2) Re @1 - that is a huge red flag implying that at least some of the people you'd be working with and who'll be evaluating you don't actually care how good your work is, just where you publish. This tells me a lot about the department culture and I would steer well-clear if you value a better, less-metric driven academia. If you relish this kind of environment, good luck 3) Honestly, these would be an advantage pretty much anywhere. At least they are honest about it. 4) Beware! Notoriously rigged searches with jobs going to internal candidates. Swedish Universities concentrate too much power in department leadership (Chair,Heads) resulting in serious abuse of authority. There is hardly any national-level funding for PhD students, resulting in a growing national crisis. A PI is lucky to even manage one PhD student. Pathetic salaries and startup.One of these departments has a serious reputation for work-place toxicity. 5) I almost appreciate the obnoxious honesty of the "desirable qualifications" of CNS and a PhD from a "internationally leading university" 6) there are some very broad generalizations above, and Uppsala has a great eco-evo group where several colleagues have spent sabbaticals to escape their own toxic departments 3) @ 4 That is not my experience of the Evo Eco departments at Uppsala at all! Searches have been so incredibly fair with hardly any internal committee members to avoid internal preferences. The only downside is the searches are very slow, and many of the best applicants accept a job elsewhere before the short list is announced. 7) @3 - in your experience, is this a matter of 3-4 months, or 6+ month timelines to shortlist? thanks! 8) in my case at one of these departments (IEG) the shortlist was within 3 months, interview at 4-5 months postapp. Also, as a new PI here I can gurantee that it's an extremely collaborative & friendly environment, that cares more about people being happy than the journals where they publish. I agree the wording of the ad is a bit unfortunate, but that's what happens when the calls come from high up / combining several depts. The start-up package is going to be very generous and salaries in relation to cost of living are extremely competitive (& you can get expert tax relief for 7 years). Happy to talk to anyone about their questions gabriela.montejo-kovacevich@scilifelab.uu.se . PS in reply to @4 internal candidates are excluded from this search because of the requirements + long/shortlists, panel reports etc are public + panels rarely have members from the departments involved, so the system is as fair as it can be imo. 4) Interested candidates are seriously encouraged to make an effort to verify the work culture with past researchers/faculty who have left these programs in this institution, and there are quite a few. There is a tendency to stifle whistle-blowers who are seen as trouble-makers, leaving them little choice but to leave the institution. In fact some programs are largely made up of a senior PI and junior faculty who were their ex-postdocs or PhD students. Past searches posted from earlier years at ecoevojobs.net have alluded to the very same problems. @2 - you are right to pick up on the red flags. 9) I agree with @4 that you should directly reach out to current PIs to ask about the environment in the departments instead of comming to share rumors and hear-say to EcoEvoJobs. Things have changed in Uppsala depts, problematic people have been pushed out and moved on to other positions; in another case an entire department was dissolved due to misconduct, etc. On the other hand, it is not my experience that PIs don't have generous starts-ups in Sweden and can't afford PhD students or even Postdocs or Senior Researchers (I am a recent PI in Sweden). PhD students are expensive in Sweden because they are contracted workers with full social benefits (as they should be!). 10) I work at IEG. This is a very special recruitment, being open for all of Biology which is why the ad is not quite what we are used to in our field. What is said above about "toxicity" etc is outdated and incorrect - there used to be "cultural problems" in one of the (many) research programs, but these were reconciled several years ago. In most program, the research enviroment is very nice, stimulating and supportive and the "problem", if any, is that people want to stay rather than leave. All in all, it's a very supportive and stimulating environment indeed. Also, this position would come with a very generous start-up/support by any standards. I strongly recommend people interested to contact people that actually work here, rather than leaning on the outdated rumours and incorrect information above. 4) ) Image is everything for Swedish academic institutions, so a lot of narrative spinning in the earlier commnets. These are not "outdated rumors" but ever-present and continuing issues. Repeated investigation by independent bodies and unions reinforce the negative academic atmosphere in Sweden. These are serious considerations that impact the life and careers of academics so awareness is important. Applicants should contact past employees to get an unbiased picture, not currently employed ones who have vested interests. Some links to important findings that have bearing are provided. https://www.gu.se/en/news/threats-and-harassment-common-in-swedish-academia, https://aardvarchaeology.wordpress.com/2017/06/02/swedish-academia-is-no-meritocracy/, https://theconversation.com/swedish-academics-suffer-widespread-threat-and-harassment-most-of-it-from-their-own-colleagues-and-students-245602. 11) wow someone needs to chill out. x7 10) I am sorry to see that someone (ie 4)) apparently has such bad experience of Sweden and the Swedish academic system. Having worked here for 20 years myself, as well as in several other countries, my experience is that Sweden is a very decent place both to live in and for academic work when related to most other countries. https://explore.sweden.se/research-in-sweden/doing-research-in-sweden

column10: This is a joint Biology Department/Great Lakes Center position. Teaching obligations are 50% of the expected obligation of full-time Biology faculty. This reduced teaching obligation will be offset by higher expectations to seek extramural funding to support research and graduate students. Teaching expectations will be in the area of aquatic biology and environmental sciences. Ability to network with local, regional, and state agencies a plus. Two external, substantive grant applications per year and productive publication activity are expected. 1) Was this a search from last year that failed? Anyone can chyme in on what it's like living in this area, cost of living, and collegiality of the department? 2) This is a restarted search. Buffalo is a low cost of living small city, many of the benefits of a large city without traffic or especially high costs. Though the housing market is competitive. 3) if im remembering correctly this search was canceled shortly after this administration started cutting funding, maybe it will stick this time? 4) What's the salary? 5) This is an R2? What's research opportunities like for grad students in the Biology Department? x 2 6) There is a graduate program in the biology department for masters students and also a great lakes center graduate program for masters students. Typically masters students get a small stipend if they are awarded a TA/GA line. 7) I disagree with the above comment on cost of living in Buffalo - I think this was the case ~10 years ago, but recently, everything is very pricey. I am a single person with a dog and a cat - in 2022, I paid $2600/month for rent before utilities (lived near S campus), in 2024, I paid $2200 for a smaller space that was very poorly managed, and I now pay $2100 to live near N campus.

It has been running since the 1930s. This event has been nominated as one of the top five large outdoor rodeos of the year multiple times, and attracts over 500 contestants each year." 3) Sounds like it might be a bit of a wild ride 4) I've been though Vernal several times. It is in a very beautiful area with lots of recreation in the desert and nearby Uinta Mountains. If I were looking for a good teaching-intensive opportunity and didn't mind living in the middle of nowhere, I'd totally go for this. 5) culture in the basin is very conservative and heavily influenced by the dominant religion 6) @5 Cool, that's how geography and religion work.

UFF has faculty and grad student chapters across the entire florida university system and there are some really amazing people working to lobby the universities and the state government to protect faculty. Being a faculty member at a public insitituation in a state run by people who are openly hostile to academics is not easy but most states with those conditions do not have a great union backing them up, you do in florida! 6) Funny that the job ad has a whole section on 'Pay Transparency' but they don't disclose the salary of this position. column10: Does anyone know the deadline for this, or even the format of the expression of interest? 1) this is going to be for someone very senior X2 2) not really for senior [ie: late-career] folks. MPG likes mid-career famous people for these positions. They typical tap people on the shoulder for directorships, so this feels like an attempt to poach people from abroad 3) How does open recruitment class as 'poaching'? 1) I think what #2 is saying is this is probably to try and get people from the US. But honeslty if you think you have a super impressive profile try it, the worst they will say is no. 4) US or not, often for these MP directorships they have already identified a few people that they want to apply and they contact them directly encouraging applications, which you could think of as targeted 'poaching' of specific people. Years ago I worked with a prof who was tapped for one and that that is exactly how it worked out. But of course that isn't a reason not to try applying anyway. 2) @3 they typically do not do open searches for directors. as @4 also pointed out, they usually seek out specific people. this unusual open call reads similarly to the 'global talent' poaching schemes that have popped up in many countries . 5) I think they wanted someone with a Humboldt Professorship, but don't know what happened there...6) @5 - the person with the Humboldt Professorship declined 7) @ 6 do you have any idea why they declined? 6) Rumours only - they wanted a lot of funding for equipment (understandable) but wasn't feasible in a small institute (it is in a village, the nearest big university is about 40 km away).  8) I recently spoke with a Max Planck director who said that, in general, they are having difficulties recruiting because people don't want relocate their labs 7) @ 8 Was that for MPIs across the board, or just this one? I can see the small town and small size of the Ploen MPI being a tough sell, espectially if the two current directors don't work hard to counter that. 8) @7 across the board

column10: The application requires unofficial transcripts. I did my PhD in the UK where we do not take courses during the PhD. Should I just explain that in the cover letter and attach transcripts from my Master's (which was more than a decade ago)? 1) Do you still have a transcript? I did my PhD in Canada and also did not have to take any courses. I have just attached my transcript with no explaination and there's never been a problem or question about it. 2) @1: I did my PhD in the UK, and when graduate transcripts are requested with applications I explain in the cover letter that they are not offered and instead provide a copy of my PhD certificate.  That has always been sufficient-, I think they just want documentation that you have your PhD. 3) I agree with @2. This is partially department/field culture. Keep in mind this is an Animal Science Department and it's normal in these department to ask for transcripts as part of the job apps. I've seen in it in other instances as well. While this job is very unique some school AS departments weigh coursework heavily because they expect you teach specific things. OP) Thanks for the advice, all! 4) The transcript serves as proof the terminal degree was completed. Nobody cares whether classes were taken, etc.

column10: SC member here - and we are looking broadly for any areas of ecology and evolution related to global change. (1) references by the deadline or just contact info? seems like the latter but no information is given. @(1) from the ad: submit a cover letter, a curriculum vitae, a concise (2-4 page) research statement, a statement describing their approach to effective teaching and mentoring, teaching evaluations and other evidence of teaching excellence, +and contact information for three references. (2) dream job alert!!!!  x7 3) question for SC member- is there any possibility for hiring at associate level or no? @3) It is only Assistant level unfortunately and @1) it is only contacts 4) Would a marine global change ecologist be considered? @(4) Yeap. Marine global change ecologists will be considered. 5) Would someone working on host-microbe relationships in the context of global change be a potential fit here? 6) Yes, host-microbe folks will be considered if their work is in the context of global change. 7) @SC, Is this position heavily focused on teaching given the teaching evaluation/performance requirement in addition to the standard teaching/mentoring statement? @7) No. Michigan is an R1 University. @ 7) answered already - but no! 8) What do you expect in the teaching evaluation/performance requirement? Do you expect all previous documents from our teaching evaluations attached to the documents? Could you please ellaborate a bit more the best way to organize this? Thanks! @ 8) please submit the materials you have available, as R1 institution research carries a significant weight in the evaluation. 9) How open is the committee to interdisciplinary research– as in having some social science research too? @9) the position is in global change biology and in an EEB department, so if there is a strong research and teaching program focused on the biology of global change, then other areas of research are also possible. (10) Does anyone have updates? 11) Is the focus primarily aquatic or will terrestrial work be acceptable? (12) The deadline is February 13, so no updates yet. And the focus is not aquatic or terrestrial...any area of global change biology will be considered. 13) You indicated a reserch statement between 2 to 4 pages, and a more detailed teaching statement with teaching evidence. So, what is the page limit for the teaching statement? I know we'll upload two different files (teaching statement + evidence) in Interfolio. @13 I think 2-4 pages for the teaching statement is fine 14) anyone know what to do about the reference upload - a separate doc for each references' name and contact info? It says 3 required and it seems interfolio is making that be that 3 documents are required @14 I personally uploaded 3 docs, 1 contact reference/doc. x4 15) Wow, 39 applied ++ those not addicted to this message board, good luck everyone!! 16) Dream job for a lot of folks - I'd bet one (1) whisky that the "real number" applied is >500!!

column10: 1) Wow! VAP but OPT STEM not eligible. any specific reason ? 2) Hi! I posted the ad. I'm sorry to say, but as a small institution and this is a 1 yr, non-TT contract position, I don't think Macalester has the capacity for OPT STEM for this job. I don't know the details, but know that HR probably added that language. If you have follow up questions, you can email the chair of the search wells@macalester.edu 3) I'm not 1, but OPT STEM requires no financial commitment from the employer and employment can vary in length as long as the student continuously remains employed (even by varied employers or going from job to job). I find it confusing that not having the capacity for it is cited as the reason, as even volunteering can be deemed an acceptable use of the OPT. 4) If the employer is not enrolled in eVerify, they cannot sponsor STEM OPT 5) Probably has to do with eVerify. The employer doesn't "sponsor" or is otherwise  involved with OPT (other tthan verifying eligibility to work through I9, whichis done for all employees including US citizens), so seems like they are just letting folks know that working for them would not meet valid employment criteria for someone on OPT.  6) Hi - #2 again. If you have specific questions about this, I encourage you to reach out to Macalester HR (hr@macalester.edu) if you need clarification. Myself (faculty at Mac) and the chair of the search have no control over visa/OPT specifications for this position.

column10: 1) Very NY specific question, but would you need a car to effectively commute from Brooklyn? Busses? 2) There are busses that go from parts of Brooklyn to Staten Island, but CSI is a little out of the way and requires a bus transfer in Staten Island. Also, some parts of Brooklyn are not served by the bus that goes to Staten Island, and so you'll need to transfer to get to even that first bus. Really depends on the Brooklyn neighborhood how much easier a car will make the trip. 3) Having a car is really a part of life for the outer boroughs (Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island), except for their most urban areas (i.e., those next to Manhattan or along a useful subway line - which is nil in Staten Island), especially if you both live AND work outside of Manhattan. You could technically rely on public transportation all across NYC, but life is just better with a car and you are not at the mercy of the MTA (esp. late nights, weekends, holidays, bad weather). If you can afford one, have one. New Yorkers know. 4) Do folks here commonly have graduate students through the Graduate Center? Or would research mentorship be primarily with undergrads? 5) CSI awards up to masters degrees, CUNY PhD students come from the Grad Center but can do research at a campus like CSI and be mentored by faculty there. 4) @1 -- one thing no one has mentioned yet is that the commute from BK to SI over the Verrazzano is expensive -- like $11 5) Can confirm. With a NY EZPass it's cheaper (like $6 and change) but it's super expensive to be doing twice a day to commute. 6) Just putting a note here that the application portal doesn't seem to work on Firefox but did work on MS Edge

column10: "Research emphasis could include marine ecology, evolution, physiology, molecular biology, conservation biology, coastal processes, nearshore oceanography, global change biology or biogeochemistry, with a preference for researchers with interest in tropical, nearshore ecosystems with a strong field-based component to their research." As someone who's previously worked with STRI, I'd be cautious about this - weird working culture that overvalues personal relationships in granting opportunities/grants/etc. and allows for abuse of people who are lower on the totem pole. +2 2) Yikes! Does not sound good. Do you think it would be possible to change this environment? 3) When I think of STRI I think of the buzzfeed article. Maybe they've improved but knowing the history can be relevant. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/nishitajha/smithsonian-tropical-research-institute-metoo 4) STRI has made lots of policy changes to prevent this stuff going forward. It's important to note that some bad stuff was done by former staff scientists, while the newer staff members have been helping to change the culture for the better. If I was cool moving to Panama, I'd take a position here in a heartbeat. 5) I have been working in Panama and been associated with STRI folks for many years. With respect to the culture, they are slowly working to make changes, but they are certainly not there yet. There are still lots of great scientists and other folks that work down there though. If you are willing to live in Panama and this fits your research, I would certainly give it a try and see what you think.

column10: 1) $72k budgeted salary - seems low? 2) If you don't like the salary then don't apply. If you want to vent about salaries in general, that's what the Venting tab is for. x11 3) I'd love to compare the distribution of actual faculty salaries with expectations from anonymous candidates on this board 4) You'd find that people who complain about salaries on this board expect salaries much higher than most places offer. And then you'd have an endless argument about whether those expectations are reasonable/justified. Are the people who complain about salaries on this board naive and unrealistic? Or are they clear-eyed critics of systemic exploitation of workers by employers? 5) Several NAU faculty have left the city/university because they couldn't buy a house in Flagstaff with faculty salary as the main income in the household. It's a pretty expensive town and not a lot of opportunities for trailing spouses. In comparison, 150 miles away the Phoenix area is the big city (culture, population, international airport) in the state but it's about 40% cheaper to live there (i.e., postdocs can buy houses). Having said that, it's lovely and NAU has done a good job with a recent R2-R1 transition. 6) @2 and kinda @4: I'm not @1, but the reason why I usually post info about salaries in the notes is because it's an incredibly imporant consideration (@5 shows one of the many reasons why this is the case). Simply saying "you're just naive" or "just shut up and don't apply" isn't conducive to bringing about change in hiring practices and pay for everyone across the board. Who cares about expectations? We ALL deserve higher wages. Punch up, not down or sideways. Solidarity. x2 6) Looking forward to someone spelling out the causal pathway from posting on this anonymous jobs board to higher salaries. Like, how is that supposed to work? Like, I can totally see how union organizing would lead to higher salaries. Or voting and political organizing on behalf of state officials who support higher education, absolutely. But...posting...on...ecoevojobs.net? What does that accomplish? 7) I'm sure Flagstaff is disproportionately expensive like @5 said, but postdocs are absolutely not buying houses in Phoenix lmao. Unless you're now considering Apache Junction and Casa Grande part of Phoenix, or have Phoenix confused with Tucson which is a much more LCOL city? Source: Phoenix postdoc renting with roommates because ASU salaries have in no way kept up with the ever increasing cost of living 8) There are ways to fight for change that don't involve clogging every discussion of every job posting with salary venting when there is a dedicated place for that. 7) But, but, if I don't complain about salaries here rather than on the Venting page, how will I generate solidarity? 9) Amen 5 again) @7, not every postdoc, esp. in ecology I guess, but I know/knew a few/was one that could. Some postdoc salaries are pretty high at ASU (like, way higher than NIH scale in the more bio-meddy institutes like Biodesign) and there are several career-track pathways that PIs use to move postdocs to higher salaries to keep them around. Anyway, perhaps not downtown PHX or some of the swankier neighborhoods, but definitely across the greater metro area, Phoenix is one of the most affordable big US cities. Flagstaff not so much, salaries are lower and the cost of housing is super high. There's not a lot of inventory since Flagstaff is surrounded by federal land, while PHX is flush with new inventory which keeps prices lower. 10) rejection email 1/26 x2 11) kind of puzzles me why only a cover letter was required 12) Does anyone who know who were the faculty that left NAU recently? @5

Does the department just not have any funds or intent to support further, and if so, wouldn't it make more sense as a postdoc/multiple postdocs? 2) Not involved there, but at our university, this would mean someone donated funds for an Endowed Professorship. Thus, the funds would be restricted to that 2) are you interpretting that it is time-limited because it says it is a 12-month position? I interpret that not as being the length of the term of the position, just that you are expected to be there working 12 months a year, even though they only have money to pay you for 9 months - which is the standard gig for most faculty, except you usually don't have to be available in the summer, whereas here you would. 3) unsure of the confusion and not my area and not at UW but...it says 12 months with 9 months salary being the endowment and the 3 months coming from grants. Fairly standard R1 expectation where you are responsible for summer salary and the expectation is you work all year. OP) I know what a 9mo salary is, I meant the part about "The initial appointment of an Assistant Professor WOT is typically for a period of three years. Renewal for a second three-year term will be considered by SAFS and the College of the Environment spring quarter of the second year." Therefore this is a temporary position. The people the endowment is named for are alive, so the intent doesn't make sense to hire faculty for possibly only 3 years, maximum 6. 4) Not sure what the confusion is about. This seems like EXTREMELY STANDARD language for this type of job. Literally no one is hired for a long-term job without an initial review period. x2 5) yes that seems like pretty standard pre-tenure/non-tenure contract structure in the US x2 6) I have been on the beat a while and was also confused by the language OP x3. 7) I assume it is permanent insofar as other non-tenure line faculty are permanent with regular review periods; worth clarifying before moving your life to a remote albeit gorgeous island.  8) U WOT M8? x2 lmao 9) I am also confused #6 and OP. If anyone from UW shows up here, do they know how visas would work for this? No green card, if not permanent? 10) my take is this is a soft money position at Friday Harbor (not main campus) with 3 year contract extensions; it's non-tenure track because the position is not being paid from recurring funds from the SAFS department annual budget, it's reliant on the endowment to continue generating the 9 month AY salary, and the selected candidate being able to bring in their 3 months of summer salary on external grants...so it seems like a relatively hard, soft money position 11) I think I saw similar three-year term language in a separate job ad and think it's just how UW does things. 12) It just looks like a permanent non tenure track position (thats how named endowed chairs work) that pays a pretty good 9 month salary (they list 116-170k/9-month to start in the ad) and you can increase that salary by getting your own grants to add more months of summer salary. Reviews and renewals are standard for all kinds of positions including pre-tenure TT positions. Honestly seems like a pretty great job all the comments here are strange. x4 13) I would gladly take this job over most TT jobs. Wish it was a better fit for me. 14) Perhaps people are asking questions because they haven't seen this type of appointment before and are curious precisely because it looks like a great job, a smidge of empathy goes a long way. x2 15) Genuine question: why don't people ever just email the search chair with these questions (and then report back, if the goal is to get answers for the community)? 16) Updated app to include question about visa status, got an email to answer the new question by 2/6 end of day "do you now or will require in the future visa sponsorship?"  17) any word fam? I got nothing as of 2/20

column10: 1) Jim Elser retiring? 2) @1 - Yes. 3) What is the salary? "competitive and commensurate with qualifications" means nothing. 4) For a position at this level, "competitive" means "likely more than you make now and we're assuming that's a fair bit". Any offer is going to be a complex negotation rather than a package deal. For what it's worth, salaries are public and the previous Director had a base of $230K in 2024. That's after a number of years so I sincerely doubt an offer would be that high, but it'd likely be well above 100K. Cost of living in MT is quite low compared to many places. 100k would be a great salary there.  5) Whoever thinks cost of living in Missoula, MT is low is living under a rock the last few years. It's incredibly expensive for a place it's size and facilities and housing prices are insane. 6) A little context, this position is based at Flathead Lake, 1.5 hours north of Missoula, and my understanding is past directors have have lived on site at the field station, though not sure how that would figure into overall compensation negotiations. 7) Further context, this position will likely not spend that much time in Missoula. The previous expectations were that the director would be on site for the majority of the year so you would be out on an island away from Missoula. A major downside would be the reduced amenties of Missoula and interactions with colleagues within the department.

Salary looks scary, but cost of living felt slightly cheaper than the US actually (I'm American). Worth mentioning I have no dependents, though. 2) Plymouth is also much cheaper than Cambridge. UK salaries in general are low, academic ones doubly so. That said I am a postdoc at another university in another part of the country on 37k and you can pay rent and live okay on that

column10: Note that Carroll now has two wildlife-related positions open -- this one in Biology, with a focus on Behavioral Ecology and Wildlife Conservation, and one in Animal Behavior with a focus on Zoo and Aquarium Studies and Wildlife Behavior.  The other job listing is available through the same link (search Animal Behavior rather than Biology).  These two positions represent a retirement replacement and expansion.  Ideally, the two new hires will build some form of a wildlife studies program at Carroll.  Non-search committee member happy to answer questions.  Review of applicants likely to begin in early January for both positions. 1) Exciting to see this program expanding! column10: Search committee member here, with a bit more additional context for ecology and evolution folks who are interested! The School of Computing and Department of Botany are jointly searching for an Assistant Professor in Applied Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML) and Geospatial AI (GeoAI) for Remote Sensing. We encourage applications from remote sensing researchers working across a diversity of ecosystems and/or scales of biological organization, with potential to contribute to the new Wyoming Forest Resilience Institute and Rocky Mountain Herbarium. For questions, feel free to reach out to the search committee chair, Chen Xu (cxu3@uwyo.edu), or the Botany Department search committee member, Lauren Shoemaker (lshoema1@uwyo.edu).

column10: 1) Can application materials be provided in English? I know in Quebec there is the expectation to learn french based on the other discussions here. But just curious as to whether an application would not be considered if it was written in english? 2) Sherbrooke is a university that teaches only in French so you will have to learn French really quickly if you don't already to meet the job requirements. 3) in principle this is okay but it demonstrates your ability to speak french and if a candidate is as good or a bit less good as you but is fluent in french, they will probably take the french-speaking candidate. If you in your statement write in a convincing way that you will learn french in principle you should be good. 4) JFC people, are we going to have this discussion on every single post from a French-speaking university??? Job applications should be written in the working language of the university/institute/etc you are applying to. If you don't have the fluency to do that, it is a big flashing sign that the job probably is not for you. 1) The job requirements don't say that you have to have french fluency but just have to be able to rapidly learn - they provide the ad in both English and French so I wasn't sure if there is an expectation one way or the other. My husband/in-laws are francophones but just my french at this point is not "fluent" but would easily get to that point if I was in an immersive environment. While I could prepare my application in French with support/help it doesn't feel honest of my current french status which I would not want to misadvertise. 5) Yeah, this is a totally reasonable question for a university in QC, in particular because the biggest universities in the province deliver their programming in english. 4) @5 The biggest university in Quebec is UQAM, where instruction is in French. * I meant  to say Université de Montréal, not UQAM. 6) @4, you are right and I agree. However, if the job as is in either in both english and french, I would assume applying in English is OK. It is up to the SC to assess the ability to learn or speak french. Vive le Québec 7) Imagine if for every job in the US people asked "am I OK if I say I'll lrean English really fast?" "Should the materials be in English, or am I OK providing them in Spanish (there are 42M native spanish speakers in the US)?" 8) @7 Many of these Quebec jobs explicitly say that candidates can learn French and that fluency for the position is not a prerequisite so this isn't an accurate comparison. Taken directly from this job ad specifically: "Professors at the Université de Sherbrooke are expected to be able to teach in French, or to rapidly attain the ability to do so. An institutional learning support program is offered to all new faculty wishing to learn French.". This implies that they are willing to consider candidates that don't have french fluency despite their location. 7) Yes, just like for US universities it is assumed that you can't teach in Spanish (unless otherwise specified), for QC universities we can assume the same (French unless otherwise specified), follow whatever is specified on the job ad (which you very kindly cited), and move on, instead of cluttering the Notes section of every freaking job where English teaching is not an absolute given... x2 1) My question was about applications not requirements for the position. I can read a job ad and can see that French is required (not to mention that the job is in QC). I just wasn't sure if these applications were expected to be prepared in one language over the other as I have not applied to any job in QC before.  The job ad does not say whether the application should be prepared in English or French which is why I even posted my question - not to discuss whether I _actually_ need to speak french.

column10: "Researchers up to eight years after PhD, counting backwards from submission deadline (cut-off date is 10.03.2018)" 1) Does anyone know what "Eligible for the WWTF grant are applicants with... (ii) being employed at a foreign research institution for at least two years in the last three years counting from the submission deadline" means? I just emailed to ask about this, as it seems like anyone who has been working overseas or recently employed in Austria in Academia is not eligible to apply which seems bizzare. 2) @1 in your email, did you happen to also ask if post-doctoral fellowships are considered employment? If not, I'll email as well. 3) @1+2, postdoc in Austria here: per the WWTF eligibility requirements, you can be currently (hired as) a postdoc in Austria if by the submission deadline you've been working in the country for less than a year. BOKU positions usually don't come with much money so they're looking for people who can bring money in and the WWTF has good success rates (it's Vienna-specific). It's a bit sad that they're limiting themselves to people who are eligible to WWTF though. 3) rejected 1/24

column10: The Curator of Biodiversity is a museum scientist who runs an independent research program as part of a team of interdisciplinary curators. 1) Is there a desired start date? [article on FORMER chief scientist removed -AP] 2) Start date negotiable but as soon as possible! 3) The chief scientist is gone but the museum leadership that drove away most of the science staff of the museum is still there. I'd suggest checking reddit and this article: https://www.clevescene.com/news/cleveland-museum-of-natural-history-workers-vote-to-unionize-in-re-run-election-47276057/ (3) Aw man! Dream job! But I have absolutely no experience as a curator. :( x2 4.) This job isn't listed on the Museum's employment website. That seems a little strange. Is that normal for museums? 5) Former CMNH CM here, I would caution anyone interested in this position. I've been out of that place for a year and a half, and hopefully they are making improvements, but it was an incredibly toxic environment. As far as I know, this would be the only curator over the inverts, herbarium, and vert zoo collection. Their priorities are out of line and they gatekeep their collections. 6) Thanks to folks who shared that link and insights about the culture - bummer to hear and I'm sorry you had an awful experience @5. I assume that all applies for the ornithology position too? Thoughts on how to assess meaningful vs. just surface-level improvements? 5) Yes, this would apply for the ornitiology position as well. I would try and talk to other folks that are not on the hiring committee/real employees if you can find their emails/info. The Natural Areas/CMs/Wildlife crew would give you insight, I think. 2) current employee, things have significantly improved and new hires are part of revitalization. Recommend talking to current curators about the job if you have questions. No previous curation experience needed (collections staff take care of day to day), looking for researchers interested in working in a museum setting! (7) is this position also visa eligible like the above one? 2) Yes visa eligible, and the Museum has sponsored/paid for green cards for curators in the past 8) Does anyone know a contact for additional information about this position? 2) You can email questions to research[at]cmnh.org which goes to current curators (9) I applied to this but the form/application seems to go through a recruiting company... anyone from the SC here that could comment on if you are seeing the applications that come through or how to confirm? x2 2) Using a recruitment firm but can confirm applications are being reviewed by museum staff as they come in 9) 12/11 -I was contacted by the recruiting company about scheudling an interivew. x3 10) 12/15 - I was also contacted for an interview. 11) Have any of you heard back?  I got an email to schedule an interview but have heard nothing since then (it's been several days) x2 10) @11 That's weird. I heard back from the recruiting firm within 24 hours of my reply and have scheduled an interview with them. I would send a follow-up email. 12) Same here; received an email to schedule an interview, answered and nothing since (it was last week). 10) was your invitation through the HR company or directly through the museum? My emails have been with the HR company.  12) with the recruiting company 13) Anyone heard anything? 14) not here - had an interview with the recruiting company a while ago but no news x2 15) at my interview the recruiter said they would be conducting more interviews in early Jan, so I expect we'll hear back in the next week or two 16) I had a 2nd interview last week. any updates? 17) @16) nothing here, but I still haven't heard anything since my first interview with the HR company over a month ago. Congrants on a second interview!!!  Was your second interview with the HR company or people at the Museum? (I'm glad someone is hearing back from them lol) 18) @17 it was with people at the museum! Thank you! They mentioned that they would try to have interviews over the next couple of weeks but that things were pretty spread out 19) any news?  20) third round interview scheduled for next week

column10: Broad search, but there is interest in adding to E3B side of the dept. Key words in ad are related to current foci area names. Teaching load for assistant prof is typically 1:1 in this dept and usually get some time off of teaching when starting. (Note this is separate from the Bioinformatics search below - different departments). (1) What is E3B? 2) Assume it's Ecology, Evolution, Environmental Bio @1+2 yes, it is one of our graduate concentrations with mol/cell/dev and biophysics being the others 3) The ad says "Applicants must be able to show proof of eligibility to work in the United States by time of hire." Does it mean that the university is not willing to sponsor a US work visa for non-US citizens? 4) @3), it doesn't say this. Either they removed it or you were lying. I hope it was the former. 5) @4 - simply saying that it no longer says this would be sufficient, assume the best, after all we're promoting an inclusive environment, and such assumptions go against such efforts X3 [plus a "hell yes"]. 6) Heads up the application requires you to submit an 'other' document whose identity is not specified, no guidance in the job ad. 7) @6 I believe that is for the 3 PDFs of publications they are requesting in the job ad. 8) any updates as of 12/30? 9) none x8 10) >350 apps, give it a minute... 11) Not to frustrate our insider, but looks like the 10x applications index is accurate once again! 12) how do we know app #? 13) @12 rule of thumb is 10x the number in the 'number applied' column. 14) the unoffical number was 370 applications, so it'll take a bit. 15) 370 apps sounds wild, is this typical for this department? 16) My guess is the very high number is also driven by a combination of A) decent sized city and B) incredibly broad call. 17) Zoom invites have been sent according to Future PI sheet 18) zoom interview invite 1/16; 19) Rejection email today 22/1 -- it was a nice cute email, which was a positive! I once got a handsigned letter! x4 20) Anyone willing to share their field who got an interview? 21) Anyone get on-site invite yet? I have not, date Feb.3  22) All the interviewees I've seen do cellular mechanisms of DNA repair.  Seems like a clear emphasis in the candidates selected and not very evo.

The search committee will absolutely accept applications from toxicologists using a One Health approach. UQAM does offer assistance to get up to speed in French, there are several allophone/anglophone profs in the department who arrived with less-than-fluency in French. column10: 1) Question for SC: the job listing says recommendation letters will be requested at a later date; however, since the application submission process is hosted by interfolio, we have the option of including the letters directly with the submission (assuming our referees uploaded their letters to interfolio). Can we include the letters with the initial submission? @1 SC member here - probably fine to include them up front if you want, we just won't look at them until later. 2) Link is broken. 3) Link works on my end. 4) @SC -  Are separate teaching and mentoring statements required? 5) Based on the wording of the job ad, I had assumed it was one document (Teaching/Mentoring) but the job application says two seperate docs are required.  4 again) @5, yes I had the same thinking so thought I would ask for the SC to clarify. @4/5 - SC member here, I realize the wording is a bit confusing, but they are two seperate statements, 2-pages each 6) Thanks for the clarification! x4 7) the add asks for 6 documents, it even numbers them 1 to 6, and they are the standard documents required on all applications. then on interfolio it asks for an extra separate mentoring statement. that not "a bit confusing" it's just a way to screw applicants at the last minute to lower the pool 8) While I blame myself for not checking the actual application earlier, this did end up costing me the application. I wonder if the SC could reopen the job call just until the end of the week to help with everyones confusion. I do not expect it, but it would be nice considering the situation. 9) This requirement is super unclear. 10) @ 7 you really think this is a strategic move to lower the applicant pool? lol 11) Lowering the applicant pool only hurts an institute. Larger applicant pools increase the chances of finding a good fit. Interfolio doesn't have "Mentorship Statement" as a type of document in the dropdown list of application materials, so categorizing it as "other document" seems like the only option if they wanted applicants to separate their reflection on teaching and on mentorship into two separate documents. 12) Any news? 13) Nothing here as of 12 Jan x9 14) Nothing here as of 15 Jan x8 15) nothing Jan 26 X8 16) Letters requested x7 17) How did you find out, did your letter writers notify you? 18) Notified about letter requests from writers, haven't heard anything directly x6 19) Zoom interview invite x5 20) Curious, they invited even before receving the letters? column10: Does anyone know if they would support H1B or green cards? 1) I think it will be unlikly sadly but, I have emailed HR to ask and will report back! 2) new faculty member in another (similar) department at URI. Happy to answer questions about the college, university, and general workload. 3) Congrats 2 - Have you heard about visa sponsorship for tenure stream faculty recently? 2) @3 unfortunately no. We are also still in a temporary hiring freeze (the state is shifting HR systems) so many things are in flux with hiring. 4) The hiring freeze is only through Nov and will not effect this job. As for H1B support, the university has paid fees for H1Bs as recently as 6 months ago, but it is not clear how the new fee structure will change things or whether it will still be in place by the time this is offered. I would apply if you're interested. There are additional jobs in related fields that will be posted soon. 5) Since there are other jobs being posted soon, if we are a terrestrial ecologist should we hold off for those? (I know this is a stupid question but working at URI is a dream) 4) I don't think a terrestrial ecologist would be considered in this search as the goal is soemone who can develop a specific program and use specific infrastructure. I don't think terrestrial ecology will be one of the jobs posted this year. 6) @4, what specific infrastructure might this be? x2 4) Sorry, posted this yestderay and it's gone now, but there are opportunites to use facilities on the GSO campus, but it is not a requirement of the job. 1 again) non commital response from HR - so maybe(?!?) on H-1B though it feels like having to drop 100k on a visa would be an easy way to remove people from applicate pool (I guess I am cynical this year...): "Visa sponsorship may be available for certain positions at the University of Rhode Island, depending on business needs at the time of hire. Sponsorship decisions are reviewed on a case-by-case basis in consultation with our immigration counsel." 4) I did get some clarity on the H1B that if applicants are in the US already on a different status, the $100k fee does not apply. This is nationally, obviously, not just for this job. 5) any intel on timeline? 6) doubt we will hear before the new year, but that'd be neat. 7) As of Jan 3rd 2026 any chance anyone has heard yet from URI? 8) nope as of 1/4 x8, 9) Nope as of 1/8 x12 10) Nope as of 1/12 x9 11) The wait for this one is killing me. I wasn't sure. Pivotal place to have a typo. 15) Considering the article specifies that the hiring freeze adheres to fiscal year 2026 (ending in June '26) and that graduate students and temp workers are in the same list as Fall '26 TT hires, I think the typo is meant to say "not." column10: 1) "CSUMB is not a sponsoring agency for faculty positions." Is this referring to visas? 2) Likely, but not on SC 3) 1 again - could someone from the SC confirm that? Or if anyone knows who the SC chair (or other members) is, please share. I could write to them and find out. I think the international folks here would appreciate knowing if it is worth applying for this position. 4) Emailed HR and they said "We have recently reached out to the Chancellor's Office for guidance on this matter and will provide you with an update as soon as we receive a response." 5) @4- Thank you! Please let us know if/when you hear back. The same policy will apply to the other two CSUMB jobs on this board, so their response should be of interest to a lot of folks. 6) In Florida we we told we had to inculde verbiage in postings explicitly stating we [the Uni] would not sponsor individuals requiring visas; the justification we were given was, H1-B visas now cost $100K 7) That is only true for H1-B applicants currently outside the US and applying for a H1-B from outside the US. The fee is not applicable to H1-B applicants currently in the US. That distinction is crucial for postdocs who are already here and are trying to build careers here. I wish university HRs would understand this. 8) @7 could you provide a link to the policy language you're referencing? I think there's a lot of confusion around renewals, extensions, and changes to employer that would be worth clarifying; 9) I am not 7, but I saw that proclamation. Found the link with info: "The Proclamation applies to new H-1B petitions filed at or after 12:01 a.m. eastern daylight time on September 21, 2025, on behalf of beneficiaries who are outside the United States and do not have a valid H-1B visa. The Proclamation also applies if a petition filed at or after 12:01 a.m. eastern daylight time on September 21, 2025, requests consular notification, port of entry notification, or pre-flight inspection for an alien in the United States." https://www.uscis.gov/working-in-the-united-states/h-1b-specialty-occupations. 10) 7 again: Yes, the original order came on Sept 19 or 20 (I don't remember exactly), but a lot of things were unclear back then including whether it would apply to extensions, renewals and changes of employers. USCIS issued new guidance on Oct 20 clarifying that it will only apply to applicants who are either outside the US or are in the US but are ineligible for extensions, renewals etc. Unfortunately, this distinction seems to have been completely lost in university admin perception, judging by the ads here. Here is a University of Michigan explainer on all of this: https://internationalcenter.umich.edu/about/news/updated-uscis-guidance-regarding-h-1b-proclamation-change-status-petitions-not-affected 4) UPDATE from HR: "Cal State Monterey Bay is currently not sponsoring H-1B employment visas which are subject to the $100,000 fee established by the “Presidential Proclamation: Restriction on Entry of Certain Nonimmigrant Workers” issued on September 19, 2025. Applicants are responsible for determining the applicability of the fee." 5) That's fair enough, I suppose. Thanks for asking and posting their response! 11) Anyone know what the page limits are for the required statments, there are no guidelines provided. 12) @11, 2 per statement i believe. 13) any news or invites ? 14) @13 not yet! x6 15) Zoom invite received 2/5 X3

column10: anyone know much about the true ability to become tenure track & do research here? 2) Based on how these kinds of positions are usually treated I would assume your chance of converting to tenure track within the department is essentially zero x4 3) @1 and 2, does that mean that statements like the following from the posting are essentially meaningless? "VCU is committed to supporting the success of its teaching faculty, who play a vital role in the university’s academic mission, and offers clear pathways for promotion to the ranks of Associate Professor and Professor." 4) They might mean Associate Professor (Teaching) and Professor (Teaching) x3 5) Yes it looks like they have a teaching track that includes promotion and probably security of employment, but it would be pretty rare to be able to switch from one of these positions to tenure track. 6) FWIW have a friend who was non-tenure track in a different dept at VCU and was never provided with a promotion opportunity over the span of 10+ years despite excellent teaching reviews and tons of service work 7) this school directs all priorities to the medical campus, so there is not a lot of faculty support on this side of campus. little financial support for PhD students (I believe it's two years of support), much of their previous graduate program webpagess are outdated as well. 8) to the point raised by the previous commentor, that is not at all true; funding is now secured for graduate students for longer, though not as high as it should be pay-wise; there are set promotion schedules for TT and non-TT as long as one has a terminal degree, w/o a terminal degree previously there was not; the school of life sciences is a new merger between biology, bioinformatics, and environmental studies; this position would involve teaching a large lecture ecology course, managing TAs and labs, and pulling one additional speciatliy class per semester. 9) FWIW, these positions are to secure teaching lines for high enrollment courses for the biology major. They are in no way designed to support a transition to TT within the same position, without applying to a new position. However, that does not mean you CAN'T do research, it is just likely going to be on your time and on your dime. That being said, most of the time these positions are gnerally secure. Meaning funding is secure for the foreseeable future and your job security is based on performance. 10) Anyone on the SC able to share an update as of 1/19? 11) Zoom invite on 2/5

Am I missing something here?

column2: The City College of New York
column10: While CCNY is an R2 because of how CUNY allocates all grad students through the graduate center, it has the research expenditures of an R1. Lots of great research going on there. 2) I interviewed here last spring and the department (especially the eco/evo cluster) was so supportive and welcoming. 3) I regard CCNY as a prestigious place to work. Dream job to me. 4) SC: Faculty at CCNY become appointed to the CUNY Graduate Center which is R1, and comment #1 is correct. 5): sorry to be 'that guy', but can anyone comment on salary vs cost of living? I know some other NY schools have accomodation support but it seems like that isn't the case here? (don't get me wrong, i'll be applying regardles) 6) Cost of living is high in NYC, but you will certainly be able to survive on this salary. A lot of people commute from Jersey, the Bronx, Westchester, and even queens and brooklyn. CCNY is on several different subway and bus lines that make this possible. Will you be able to live on the upper west side, maybe not, but Harlem is also not so expensive as the rest of manhattan 5) thanks for hte context 6! 6) Assistant professor in this department has super strong research record. People caring if CCNY is R2 or R1 is quite ignorant about how things are going there. 7) That salary is definitely feasible to live in Manhattan (by yourself). I live in Manhattan on a similar salary 8) @6 chill out. No one was complaining about R1/R2 status, someone was just explaining the administrative structure x2; 9) Does anyone have info about the statement "Candidates must be legally authorized to work full-time in the United States." does this mean only apply if you ar a US citizen or already live and work there? :/ 10) @9, generally that means US citizens and permanent residents (green card holders) 11) @9 It's still worth applying for it if you have a strong profile! H1B application does not need 100k anymore if you are already in the states legally.  @10 & @11 Thanks for the clarification. Not in the US at the moment, theferefore, applying seems like a recipie for frustration ... so sad, my profile fits quite well, I know people in that department and can asure they are awesome. 12) New mayor!!  [kinda mean, snarky comment removed -AP] 14) @12 does not change a thing in this climate! 15) application does not give a field to submit statements .. 16) I submitted them under the 'writing sample' option and just titled the submission as e.g. 'research statement' 17) My last application. Good bye academia if this doesn't work. Tried enough. Very happy that finally done with ~100 applications over many years! 18) any word? 19) Nope x8 20) no word as of 1/16 (x4). 21) Any news as of 1/30? 22) Nah 23) Based on other CUNY postings, it usuallly takes 2 months to see a Zoom invitation news. 24) SC told me they probably wouldn't get to the applications until late January due to CUNY rules, so I'm dormant thinking about this until February. 25) no news 2/3 x 8 26) 2/12 no news x6 27) Anything as of 02/16? 28) Nothing for me! x4 29) 2/18 in person interviews offered (x2)

column10: This is a broad search for two positions, which can be either in the Department of Microbiology or Evolution, Ecology & Organismal Biology. Microbiome science includes "microbiomes in any ecosystem context (natural environments, plant/animal/human hosts, or engineered), organismal focus (microbial eukaryote, prokaryote, virus, or mix), and approach (wet-lab and/or computational) that aims to advance foundational organismal, ecological, evolutionary, and/or mechanistic understanding in a microbial community setting." 2) this due date was orginially last week.... damn....3)@SC I saw that letter writer names will be requested from me about 72 hours after submission—does that mean my recommenders will then receive the request to submit their letters? Basically should I recommend my letter writers to submit within those 72 hours? 4) I applied, they reached out to me within 72 hours to fill in details for referees, but the letter writers have onger than that 5) from 3 thanks @4! 6) BTW the due date on this app has not changed..#2 might be thinking of a separate search in microbial cell biology - the microbiome science search is entirely distinct from that. 7) pretty sure this job was sent to ecolog 10/10 & the due date said 10/15? 8) If so then that was an error - the due date is Nov 2nd. 8) Top of the link says Nov 6. Does anyone know if they are still accepting applications?? 9) Emailed Matt Sullivan and got an autor reply. 9) Applications will be accepted through the 6th. 11) Any updates? 12) None here 12/12 13) coming from the future to warn us? @12 14) does anyone know when rec letters are due? 15) I think rec letters were already due, got an email at 11/6 that they had issues with their system asking to reenter the rec letter writer's details. They also reached out again last week (11/15) for a missing letter. 15) anyone invited for zoom interview? 16) not me at this time (Dec.3) x7 17) Nothing Dec 10th x7 18) Anyone heard as of Dec 19th? 19) Nothing here x6 20) Anyone from the department/search committee who can update us? 21) Was anyone brave enough to email the head of search committee? 22) I assume they moved forward and no one on ecoevo was a zoom finalist, because it is now so late in the timeline. 23)21 again. I initially thought that @22 but we are such an awesome bunch. At least one of us would've gotten a zoom. 24) agree with 22, they maybe wanted a more medically or industrially focused person. 25) I wouldn’t lose hope yet. This is a big cross-unit search and the delayed letters + holidays probably slowed things down. 26) lol someone be brave & ask for us! 27) okay, I emailed and got an autoreply - SC chair away this week 28) @27 is the hero we don't deserve. Hopefully the person replies soon. 29) on-campus invites sent x2 30) Ouch! that's the last one I thought I'd get a chance in :( good luck to those selected for interviews!!

column10: 3yrs fixed term, possibly renewable, 75-105k GBP salary. ARIA is a UK public-funded body (taxpayer money, startup vibe). Ideal for an academic wanting a change of air to do something super exciting for 3 years. We're figuring out how to best use 55million GBP to try to create a gamechange in how humanity interacts with nature. Will be highly technical & managing the teams we fund. https://www.aria.org.uk/opportunity-spaces/engineering-ecosystem-resilience 1) do they sponsor visa for international candidates? x2 2) even if they do sponsor a visa, interational candidates will be on the hook for the added NHS fees, which can be thousands of pounds upfront 3) What are the added NHS fees for international candidates? I am not familar with this... 3) It's essentially covering the taxes you would have paid to contribute to the NHS.  It's around £1000-1200 per year.  It gets you access to the NHS for "free" (covered by the taxes/surcharge you pay). 4) You'll pay double for the NHS. NI will still be deducted from your pay every month. 5) OP here -Yes ARIA does sponsor visas  - a huge % of our staff are international -  the HR/People ops team are super professional and much more agile than a university might be. Don't let yourself  get distracted by this kind of detail - like nhs/relocation costs etc - I'm certain that that can all be easily sorted with the right candidate. 6) any updates on this process?  7) interview invite received 12/19 x3 8) any updates on this process? 9) second interview invite received last week

column10: Any opinion about Laredo? 1) amazing bugs!  It's in the Rio Grand Valley which is a highly impoverished area. Very low cost of living and the opportunity to teach a very under-served population.  2) Is it good place to live with a family? I have 2-year old son and new born. 3) I would look into what Texas is doing to K-12 education first. 4) The cost of living in Laredo is not low..., lower than Austin, yes, but compared to many other places in the state/country it's about the same. Most outsiders don't care for it, which is why there is a lot of turnover in the faculty at this university.  5) Median home price is $215k, about half the average for the US. Definitely low cost of housing. 6) Grew up in the area and long time Laredo resident. That median price is not a fair representation of the reality of housing in Laredo. Not willing to pursue the argument further than that, take it for what it is and apply to the job if you are interested. 7) I backed out of an interview for a position there previously because I had an unofficial job offer elsewhere and the faculty I interacted with were somewhat hostile/unprepared and the position reeked of desperation after multiple failed searches and subsequent failed searches in the years that followed. 8) @7, can you explain what you mean by "unprepared"? I am also curious to hear if this was within the Entomology department or if it was elsewhere at A&M? 9) @8 By the way, this position is at Texas A&M International University not the department of Entomology at Texas A&M. 10) Be aware that Laredo is fully within border patrol territory. Anywhere within 100 miles of the border a lot of US constitutional rights officially don't apply. There are permanent checkpoints and a heavy BP presence. 11) I visited for an interview at the Bio Dept. Laredo gave me a sense of something between suburbia and boomtown. Campus is surrounded by gorgeous mesquite shrubland. Deer and javelinas roaminhg free everywhere on campus 12) zoom invite 1/8 x4
