column10: Canada Research Chair, Tier 2; 1) "In recognition of the underrepresentation of racialized scholars in our chairholders, and in accordance with Section 10.1 of the Alberta Human Rights Act, only applicants who self-identify as a racialized individual will be considered for this CRC opportunity." Does this mean someone needs to be BIPOC to apply? 2) Yes but a woman or LGTBQ also has a shot - EDI is baked in to the Tier 2 CRCs. 3) I feel racialized after reading the +1 4) Godspeed BIPOC applicants! (5) I would check with the search committee because the federal program restricting Tier 2 CRCs to DEI candidates has not been applicable for several years. 2) "all institutions that accept agency funding must make concerted efforts to meet their equity and diversity targets and provide a supportive and inclusive workplace. This supports the goals of equity, diversity and inclusion within the CRCP and the broader Canadian research enterprise." https://www.chairs-chaires.gc.ca/program-programme/equity-equite/index-eng.aspx 6) so basically no white guys? 7) yes, so basically no white guys 8) Seems like disabled white guys are a maybe. Also, it looks like their ability to restrict applicants to underrepresented people is contingent on the university not having met equity targets 9) given the extensive of the application, it would be good if the SC could confirm if only BIPOC applicants will be considered or if women, LGBTQ, disabled applicants would also be considered. 2) this is serious stuff - another Candian university lost their CRC2 funding and entirely cancelled a search/pulled a position and hired no one because their short list wasn't diverse enough. Just a few years ago. 6) @2 that's crazy... and while I'm a white guy who definitely would have wanted to apply for this job, I get it. Frustrating but I get it. 10) honesty I feel pretty discouraged when I see positions like this. Not because of the position, but the comments... 11) what about white guys that identify as two-sprit or non-sexual?  2) @ 10 very easy to say until it swings back against you. Discrimination is either ok or it is not ok. While this is going on, the Canadian government has determined that "woman" is no longer a equity-seeking or desrving group (b/c the public service is majority female now). i know more than a few white women who  loved tweeting about EDI stuff who were outraged they were denied jobs because of that.  https://universityaffairs.ca/news/parliament-reviews-edi-for-research-grants/ 12) I managed to confirm with the SC that the position is specifically for racialised applicants due to a short fall in this diversity category. 13) Will white transgender and/or non-binary people be considered for this position?  14) FYI: https://universityaffairs.ca/news/alberta-panel-recommends-new-funding-framework-dropping-edi/ Sorry @ 13, those groups aren't diverse enough to merit EDI considerations anymore. 15) categories other than "racialized" will be triaged by human resources. I work at U Lethbridge and that is what happens across the board with job advertisements like this. So other under-represented groups are unlikely to be seen, never mind considered by the search committee. Also our salaries and the town is not the most welcoming of places to live. A job is a job, but don't say that you weren't warned. 16) Can someone please confirm that Tier 2 Chair is equivalent to Assistant Professor? I am a postdoc, and confused whether I am eligible or not. It sounds to me more like a department chair position. 17) @ 16 it's a research chair (research-intensive professorship) not a department chair. CRC2s are the earlier career category of CRCs but they can be hired at the Assistant or Associate level depending on the department's desires and the experience level of the candidate. - thanks! (from 16). 18) does anyone have an update on whether they have selected a long/short list? 19) nothing here 20/11

column10: 1) Focus on study of "resilience" so despite being broad in terms of taxa and approaches it won't be a fit for many organismal biologists 2) SC member here - we are interpreting 'resilience' very broadly and would encourage organismal biologists working on a wide variety of topics to apply! 3) Letttsssss goo!!!!!!!! Hands down best job this year! 4) @2 thank you for the clarification! Very helpful to know. 5) saw a post on bsky saying they want a plant pathology person for this position 6) No. SC member here again. The plant pathology search is a *different* position. This search is for an organismal biologist, broadly defined. (Also, the other search is for a "Plant Molecular Biologist" not specifically pathology) 7)@SC language around references is a bit confusing so just to confirm you want us to put the info of our  letter writers both in the cover letter and the  respective section on the application? And they won't be contacted during this initial phase? I  just want confirmation whether my letter writers would be prompt after I hit submit so I can coordinate. 8) Yes, the online system also asks you to input names and email addresses for references, but letters will be pulled at a future point. 9) Add says "Preference will be given to candidates whose work complements UNC-CH’s strengths in Ecology, Evolution, and Organismal Biology". Are there evolution people in this department? Looks like a good Ecology group in a very molecular-heavy dept. 10) https://bio.unc.edu/research/evolution/ 11) I'm a marine community ecology / org bio prof in this department (Biology @ UNC): yes, we have a v strong EEOB group of ~30 peeps within a very large and diverse department with a lot of cancer & developmental biology people. (And we have our own core sequencing and microscopy facilities). The dept is fanatstic with superb leadership, amazing UGs, awesome v progressive local community etc. We are doing 6 searches this year (typical). And we have a field station in the Galapagos!  https://galapagos.unc.edu/  12) 11, are you able to share what the other searches are for?  There's this job, the two teaching jobs, and the plant molecular job ... any others? 13) Will this position sponsor H-1B visas for candidates who are already based in the US? 14) This is a great 'starter job'. Several peeps have started here to move to more permanent jobs later. Apply! 15) I'm guessing that 14 meant to make this comment about a different job?  I don't think many people would consider UNC Chapel Hill (one of the best public universities in the US) a "starter job" ... 16) Here the review date says 11/3 but the online job ad says it closes 11/10. Can anyone provide insight on this? 17) SC member here: we will begin to review the applications on 11/3; the electronic system will continue to accept applications through the 10th. Also, I very much agree that this isn't a 'starter job' - I moved here from another position and plan to stay! 18) Yes, that is a crazy uninformed take, if intentional. Unless getting poached up the road by Duke or by an Ivy or UC school, nobody is leaving Chapel Hill. 19) Can people who think this is a starter job please not apply. UNC is literally my dream school, and I would really like less competition. Thank you! :-) ALSO leaving UNC for a UC school is craaazy work, respectfully!  20) Any updates? 21) not here x5 [article on FORMER professor removed -AP] 24) any word? 25) not yet! x2 26) anyone know who the chair of the search committee is? 27) if you're asking for an update 9 days (checking here 11/19) after the portal closes (which was 11/10), lemme just share - relax. This is going to take at least several weeks. 28) Letters requested 11/19, though not sure if this is a universal letter request 29) Were you notified about the letter request? 30) Looks like you can check to see if letters were requested in the application portal... mine say "no". Can anyone confirm that theirs says "yes"? 31) Yes, mine were solicited yesterday (date/timestamp present) x4 32) Zoom interview request 11/21 x2 33) What are grad student stipends like in this department? 34) Campus interview invitation received 12/10 x2 34) Any updates on the Plant Molecular Position from this department? 35) zoom interview but no on-campus invitation -- possibly awaiting rejection email? or maybe just along for the ride..

column10: SC member here, happy to ans questions :) Friendly department with a strong emphasis on teaching 1) what's the salary range for this position? 2) except that questions ;) 3) "Except that question" is the best post of the year! 4) will a candidate with evolutionary genomics background be considered if they propose future conservation work? 5) same question as 4, plus wonder if we can request letters if we get past initial screening. OP: @1) Let me see what I'm allowed to say on this... I'm not sure tbh. @4) Yes, we are open to broader interpretations of "Wildlife/Conservation Genetics"; and @5) Yes, the decision for this was mostly to cut down on the number of AI applications we get.. We just want to know you're a real person serious about applying for this position. We are happy to receive letters after initial screening if you're a serious candidate. 6) This probably demonstrates my naivete but im surprised that there are many AI TT applicants 7) curious if anyone has any thoughts about the culture at Weber State. particularly religious/LDS? what about DEI efforts in particularly those promoting queer community? are the faculty members (and people reviewing the application) likely to be LDS? OP @7) Ogden is located ~40 min north of SLC, with several faculty members in the department commuting from the city daily. In my experience neither city is particularly religious relative to the surrounding areas, but if you ask a different person with a different community you may get a different response. I can only speak for myself but I am not religious, and your religious beliefs will not be limiting in any way during the application process. We value diverse thoughts and humans, but as of recently we're not allowed to use certain language in our call for applications. I asked a colleague for input as well and their response is the following: "I think it is fair and accurate to say there are places in the country that are a lot better with The DEI stuff and places that are worse.  The same would hold true with religion.  Typically university campuses have been islands that can buffer against these things in the more conservative states but unfortunately lately that has not been as true.  Fingers-crossed that the pendulum swings back soon." @1) All salaries for Weber State professors in the state of Utah are publically available at https://transparent.utah.gov/ 8) any updates? 9) none on my end 10) zoon interview invitation (Dec 2) x3 11) on-campus interview invitation (Dec 20) x2

column10: "tenure stream, possible joint university appointment" 1) Amusing to see so many typos "Evolving for the 2st Century", "The Position: Curator or Birds"... 2) Curator or Birds: Birds 3) I suggest they use Grammarly. 4) Made my day @2 :))) 5) Any questions people have about the position? 6) Page limit on the cover letter? 7) None formally listed, but conciseness is usually appreciated... 2-3 pages is usually appropriate; 8) aim for one page... SC appreciate that. Most times I have gone for interviews have been on 1pg latters. 9) thanks I mainly ask because there is no request for a research statement here. 10) is there a list of the types of algae and plants (especially bryophytes)  included in the herbarium? I assume mainly green macroalgae? 11) Application guidelines says that cover letter should include "salary requirement" -- is that common for this type of position? Anyone who has come across something like this before would mind giving advice on how to include that in the letter? 12) wow, that is a long task list with a lot of buzzwords for how to make an impact. i'm burned out even before applying. good luck to those who do. 13) @ 11 I would take it as an opportunity to briefly indicate where you might expect to fit in the provided salary scale, based on experience / current position, etc. It wouldn't override a later negotiation if the application/interview was succesful... 14) screening interview invitation 11/22 15) updates? 16) no updates (as of Feb12) 15again) post-screening rejection email today - good luck to those who moved on!

column10: "tenure stream, possible joint university appointment" 1) Amusing to see so many typos "Evolving for the 2st Century", "The Position: Curator or Birds"... 2) Curator or Birds: Birds 3) I suggest they use Grammarly. 4) Any questions people have about the position? 5) How open is the Musuem to folks interested in integrating collections and field data? 6) Highly. Most museum curators actively grow their collections through field campaigns that contribute to their research; 7) @5, if you ask that question during an interview for a museum position you will likely be eliminated from the process -- it shows a clear lack of understanding of museum research // I dont mean to be mean, but I have worked in museums for many years and seen this happen in searches. 8) I don't mean to be mean. LOL x1 9) note that the low end of the salary is not enough money to live in Toronto 10) @4 - do you have a sense for how much of a traditional curator you all are after?  If someone uses specimens/collects, but is focused on ecology/global change not systematics/ornithology would that be viewed as outside the bounds of what you're after? thx! 11) Screening interview requested (yes, prior to close date). x4 12) @11 hope the screening interview goes well. Now I feel guilty for not getting to this application sooner!! 13) best of luck to all. 14) Reference checks for finalists are underway. x2 15) Have a post-reference check interview scheduled

column10: Microbiology teaching preferred; any research focus invited. 1) Does "begin by" December 1 mean it's best to get apps in as soon as possible? 2) Applications will be downloaded to review on December 1st. 3) If you are part of the LGBTQ+ community, read about this school on Inside Higher Ed before applying, some concerning things in the last few years x2 4) Heads up that the application portal seems to be contacting references immediately upon application. 5) Following up on 3): "the College can neither condone nor support sexual activity outside of the marital relationship between one man and one woman"-from their school website (seems like relevant context since many of our colleagues looking for research opportunities are lgbtq+); 6) Do you usually require your employer to support what you do off-campus? I'm a queer faculty member at this institution, and of course it has issues, no one's denying that, but there are gay, queer, and trans students, faculty, and staff all in community here. Is it a struggle, sometimes yes! But it's literally also a struggle everywhere, and it doesn't seem fair to target this specific department (which has no record of issues in this respect). 5) "Target" this department by sharing information that's literally on the college website? It's good to know that there are lgbtq+ faculty and students, but it's also good for prospective applicants to know up front what the college's stated position on same-sex couples is. Sure it's a struggle everywhere, but that doesn't excuse queerphobic institutional policies and positions. 6) It seems wrong to specifically call out Providence's biology department while ignoring some of the other postings here that are from institutions with very homophobic pasts and/or in states that are openly homophobic. 5) No one is calling out their biology department 7) Rejection notice 12/16 x7 8) no rejection but no zoom interview yet... 9) Zoom 12/16 10) Hear anything after the zoom? 9 again) campus interview offered

column10: 1) Strongly suspect this position is just a formality for permanently hiring an internal candidate on a postdoc-to-faculty transitional contract with this precise research program and research profile, do not waste a lot of time with this one. 2) I can confirm the suspiscions of 1. x2 3) Yes, most definitely a internal hire of postdoc-to-faculty. Not worth applying... 4) counterpoint, do these scenarios ever go another way? what if genuinely stronger candidates who fit the ad apply? 5) I would assume no 4, since in these tight budget times the $$ will be there for legacy commitments (like a postdoc to tenure track program) but not for an actual new hire. 6) can confirm this is in fact an internal hire. x2 7) Having served on a search committee that was intially intended for an internal hire, yes, they do sometimes end up going to someone external. Chances are low, but it does happen. 8) If an inside candidate is smart they are always applying for other jobs anyway, so there is always a chance they get an offer they like better and the SC moves on even if they had planned to hire internally.

It says 12 contact hours but it's not always clear what that means in practice at different places. @ 2, i think it was 4 courses a term, first year you only do 3  3) How do you know it was a failed search? Asking bc people on here get it wrong a lot... 4) I was the failed search and turned it down because of the teaching and research expectations with no start up, made me sad to turn them down 5) everyone in this department is super nice and suportive! 5) Does that mean 4 separate lecture courses per term? How do labs count? Would it be common for some of those to be multiple sections of the same course? It does seem like an awful lot of teaching to still have a research expectation.6) 4 lecture courses or 2 lecture/lab courses a term 7) Doesnt' matter how supportive the faculty are, 5, if the school doesn't support the research. @1/4, Is "no startup" no startup, or low startup? 8) << question 7! Is it no support or start up funding at all? Do multiple sections of the same course count or is it four seperate lecture courses or two seperate lab courses each with multiple sections? Also it says review date is November 10th on the posting. 9) I am not on the SC but am a newish fac member. You can teach multiple sections and that still counts as contact hours (first semester was easy, all lower labs with all prep done). I applied for the $5000 internal grants every year, and had students apply for $1000 student grants. All equipment I needed was here. It is a public PUI and it is less research supported than some others that I applied for but tenure is more weighted on teaching. I still should have a few papers before tenure, but not as many/in as prestigious journals than if I had more time to focus.

column10: 1) Job add says "ABD will not be considered". Does this mean a) ABD will not be considered if not awarded by hire date, or b) ABD wil not be considered if not awarded by application review date? 2) For us mortals, what is ABD? 3) ABD = "All but dissertation", which refers to advanced grad students who just need to finish their dissertation/defense to earn the PhD 3) Ad says postdoc required along with ABD not considered. This means a degree by hire date still would not meet qualifications. 4) I thought ABD was "All but DEGREE", meaning the dissertation had been defended and the candidate is just awaiting the official awarding of the degree. "All but degree" and "All but dissertation" are two VERY different things. 4) @2, I was also under the impression this was the meaning (semantics maybe), @ 3, I don't think that's strictly correct. One could walk this December and have a post-doc lined up for Spring to get 8 months of post-doc experience before the hire date and meet all the requirements before that date but not the application deadline date. OR, they could defend this January, get hired as a "post-doc" and walk in May (stranger things have happened). Sounds like an unlikely scenario, but I happen to know someone in this exact situation. 5) What is the teaching load? 6) Nah ABD definitely refers to the actual work of the dissertation/defense, not the awarding of the degree (although that is relevant to your employer as well). Defending and submitting the dissertation is the final requirement-- everything else is just waiting on the academic calendar. Actually, I think it means both :) because you are definitely ABD until your degree is posted. 7) 6 is right and it isn't uncommon for people to be ABD for 3+ years. 8) Back to 1's original question, you are unlikely to meet the minimum qualifications they have set out for the job. If they don't have enough applicants, the search may fail instead of you having a shot. I wouldn't put effort behind this one. 9) emailed chair and can confirm that PhD completed with postdoc experience by application date of Nov. 1st to be considered (as stated in the minimum qualifications). 10) @1, I can't tell if some folks are being passive aggressive here but it's a reasonable question to ask, especially when MANY R1 institutions don't limit their applicant pool like this, at least not this explicitly, and many times the minimum qualifications are required by the time of appointment... looks like you have your answer. 11) Is there a way to move to this to a discussion. Most of this is not relevant to the ad now that we are clear on desired qualifications. I'm more interested in teaching load and research expectations. Looks like it is 21k students! 12) Funnily enough this isn't the language we agreed on in our department meeting. Should have said quantitative biologist. 13) @12 does that mean y'all are looking for a bioinformatician or is quantitaive ecology in the scope of the search? 14) Based on my reading of the ad, I don't think bioinformatics would be considered. Hopefully, @12 could provide an answer as I'm on the fence about this one. x2 15) any updates? 16) Nothing so far 3x 17) Still no news? 18) Request from search committee to share application with the rest of the department (12/2) x2 @18 Sorry, I didn't understand that correctly; did the search committee request other members of the department to see/check the applications? 18 again) Yes, it was an email from the search committee asking for permission to share application materials with the rest of the department (not sure specifics of why they are sharing). I haven't received any information about interviews or anything else related to where they are at in the process. 19) Invitation for Zoom interview recieved (12/11)x3 20) Invited for on-campus interview 1/7

column10: 1) It begins! "the University may not be able to offer H-1B sponsorship. Particularly the University is not able to pay the $100,000 payment accompanying new H-1B visa petitions." Good for US applicants, but unfortunate for those who haven't achieved green-card status yet. 2) So if international candidates getting an offer, this essentially means if you want the job you need to pay. Not the time and place sorry but what a shite situation x2 3) The (prospective) employee cannot pay any of the H1B visa fees. It is the employer who applies for, and pays for H1B. In other words, H1B is permision for a US employer to hore a non-US citizen, not permission for a foreigner to work for a US employer, so the university would need to pay the 110K (or whatever the visa costs). 4) I feel like that should/could be negotiated with the start-up budget?

column10: 1) They have accepted late apps before 2) I think this is definitely not an eco-evo job. 3) @2, read the site info tab. Anatomy and physiology positions are in scope. 3) Faculty in department— our animal physiology faculty do a lot of crossover in Ecology and Evolution. Most teach ecological or organismal classes in addition to physiology— we still have a lot most of the "ologies" in our department. 4) @3, do you have a sense for whether apps submitted after 9/15 (i.e., now) will be considered? 3) @4 Yes definitely— SC emailed the dept to ask that we share the position this morning (9/30). I do think they're reviewing as they go, so I would suggest getting something in as soon as you're able if interested. 5) @2 and others - I am a vertebrate anatomist/physiology and an eco-evo person - most of us are! Unfortunately, it is so common for there to be a comment along the lines of "this isn't an eco-evo job" when a position in this field is advertised here. Almost always, those positions are eco-evo, and certainly eco-evo enough to be posted here. It would be great for there to be more restraint against such comments. Those of us in that field deserve to know when jobs become available. x5 6) Any updates? Wondering if they reviewed late applications. 7) Another faculty in the department. The wording on the add is misleading as the review starts as soon as the ad is live, this is not the deadline. This wording comes from upper admin. Applications are still being reviewed. @7) thank you!

column10: Teaching responsibilities for this position include teaching the Introductory Biology sequence (BIOL 100 and BIOL 200), which includes lectures and laboratories. The successful candidate will be responsible for teaching two 4-credit courses (and two associated laboratory sections) per semester, will coordinate the multi-section introductory sequence among instructors, and will contribute to departmental level service and student advising. The successful candidate will also offer a research program in either biology education research or a disciplinary research specialty. In either case, research with students will be expected and will support important experiential learning high impact practices. 2) Wow a 4 is an already fairly heavy load and then to be the coordinator is often some sort of release. 4+coord is brutal 3) 4 credits is the standard for all courses here; in this case it means the teaching load will be 2 lecture sections, likely both intro bio. So not actually a heavy load for a SLAC and less than the standard load in the department (2 lecture sections + 3 lab sections). I'm current faculty and happy to answer any other questions. 4) Any updates on status? Anyone get some positive news? 5) crickets here (11/19) 6) Zoom interview early Jan

Seems like a cool place to do wetland/aquatic work. 2) Worth noting "We especially encourage candidates with expertise in fish and fisheries ecology." 3) @1 I think it's one of the best aquatic ecology departments in the world. It will be hyper competitive. x3 4) I interviewed in this dept. earlier this year and was very impressed with everything, definitely world renowned in limnology as well. 5) @1 it's only the birthplace of limnology in north america. CFL is an incredible group, very collaborative. wish I did fish. madison is also amazing... 6) Is it worth the energy for folks who are non-fish aquatic researchers to apply? 7) I'm not sure anyone but the search committee can speak to that (and they won't). However, I know a fisheries researcher is leaving and I suspect this is intended to replace them. Assuming that's true, the odds for non-fish folks might be slim. But that's largely speculation. 8) will remain anon but I am currently employed at the center for limnology, I can confirm it is an incredible place to work with a great collaborative atmosphere and wonderful scientists.We are a famliy for sure and having the NTL LTER collaboration is awesome. They will definitely be  looking for a fish-centric researcher. 9) I did my PhD at this institution in a different department - but this department had a great reputation campus-wide.  10) I'm the "fisheries researcher [who] is leaving" mentioned by 7 and I can also confirm that this is an amazing place to work - family/geography pulled me away - nothing that should concern applicants. @10) Can you confirm if they will only evaluate applications that are fish-focused or if there 11) Not sure how your question would have ended, but as #10 is leaving the institution I doubt they can confirm anything about the search. Heck, I’ve never even felt comfortable making guarantees as to the future actions of the search committees on which I’ve served. Faculty are unpredictable, especially in groups. If you’re interested in the position and think you can put together an app that answers the posting (or even comes close) then you should go ahead and apply! 12) genuine question, originally the posting had some formating issues where CV and research statement were bunched up and had a "(2 page maximum)" line after them much like the teaching/mentoring does currently, but I see that neither of these have page limits attached, is anyone abiding by the previous for their research statement? 13) Has anyone heard anything??? 14) No, but it has only been 10 days since applications closed. It will take some time for the search committee to work through a likely robust candidate pool. 15) Adding to #14's comment, many of those days fell across a US holiday. I think it is likely that zoom interview invitations will go out before the Christmas holiday but also wouldn't be completely surprised if they waited until early January for that. Big searches like this tend to progress slowly and the US holiday season doesn't help with that. 16) also, was on a search with similar timeline ~2-3 years ago elsewhere as a grad student, interview invites for that search werent sent out until in Jan but we didn't bother with any Zoom and went straight to in-person with that. 17) any news? 18) Letters requested 12/10. 19) So folks without letter requests are SOL?? 20) That's usually how it pans out 21) @19 they are definitely missing out on some terrific candidates, consider yourself in good company 22) any updates? Has zoom happened already? 23) I hope not! Crossing my fingers for those of us still in the game. 24) it's a little odd to hear nothing since letter request - I'm hoping too that we are still in the game 25）I am in UW-Madison and I know the campus talks for candidates have been scheduled. 26) Well, that sucks. Ah well. x 2

column10: [link updated -AP] 1) Friendly dept with emphasis on conservation/restoration, great students, affordable city/good place to raise kids, near some nice forests, reasonable teaching load, lots of local funding/research opportunities on Great Lakes ecosystems. Looking for an ecologist with a strong statistical background (research and teaching). Happy to answer questions. 1) looks like teaching load is 3-3 2) I am interested in applying to this position, but is soil ecology going to be considered as a relevant field?  3) I was trying to find info on the "Department of Natural and Applied Sciences" named in the job ad but... apparently that department doesn't exist? It might have been renamed, or absorbed? Heading to uwgb.edu/nas redirects to the College of Science, Engineering, and Technology. Can SC weigh in? 4) SC here. SC here. @1 teaching load is currently 3-4, but that includes labs. The WI legislature is planning on moving everyone to 4-4, but the plan is to better account for research student supervision and so teaching load might actually decrease. @2 we have several faculty who study elements of soil and water quality, given the agg/industry history of the region – so sure! @3 like many places our organization can be a little confusing. The College (CSET) houses three departments: engineering, human biology, natural sciences. The Department of Natural Sciences is a functional unit, but subdivided into bio, chem, phys, envi-sci, geo – which correspond to the majors and MS programs. The website is student-facing and so it is organized by college, and then by programs – with faculty listed in the program sections. Weird, but functionally it works. 5) Is there a startup offered with this position? If so, what could be expected? I am not asking for a specific amount, but rather what the startup would typically cover. 6) @5 Yes, but probably an order of magnitude lower than an R1 startup. Mine covered a lot of field equipment, but not big-ticket items or staff salary. There is internal money for big items, and they tend to be purchased for the entire dept (pool vehicles, lab instruments, boats, manufacturing equip. etc). Research expectations for tenure reflect this. 7) Is it reasonable to expect starting salaries here to be similar to UW-Stevens Point and other regional UW schools? For example, UW-SP is ~$59,000/year staring, also do opportunities for summer teaching exist? 8) @7 same ballpark (maybe a little more), but I don't know the specifics. Luckily, in GB you can still buy a house for 200k. Yes, there are summer teaching opportunities. 9) Has anyone heard any updates on this one? 10) Not yet x6 (11/18) 11) We are still reviewing the applications and will schedule phone interviews very soon. We had ~115 very well qualified applicants. 12) @11, thanks for letting us know! x2 13) Zoom interview received 11/24 x2; 14) Any updates 01/07/26? x3 15) No updates yet (01/30)

column10: Do your research on recent events at TXST and in TX higher ed in general before applying here 2) did my phd here and talk with my advisor a lot still, things aren't looking so good. several facutly were recently fired/let go because of social media posts, and they also mentioned how students are purposly trying to get facutly in trouble. 3) no faculty have been fired for social media posts yet, at least not to public knowledge 4) https://www.insidehighered.com/news/quick-takes/2025/09/23/texas-state-prof-sues-claiming-free-speech-contract-violations 3) again, no one has been fired for /social media posts/. Those were rumors idependent of that article, which is unfortunately true and why people should do their research before applying. 5) Please everyone, do your research and avoid applying for this job (so that we have less competition...)  6) deadline extended to 10/31 7) the town looks like a nice area to live and work, too bad about the state politics, it would be great to know how women feel there? 7) Female PI in the department.. our new chair is a woman and absolutely fantastic. University is great in that regard (i.e. little to no misogynistic issues). Broader culture isn't bad, but we have similar laws to most red states. I would encourage you to apply and then talk to some of our younger female faculty for honest takes (it probably varries across individuals) 8) any updates? 9) 6-Nov: received invitation to Zoom interview 10) any updates? 11) 25-Nov: invitation for campus visit

column10: Faculty member here - FGCU Biology is a great department. The school uses a tenure-track-equivalent system, with a rolling three year contract. The faculty union is strong and we have been largely insulated from the politics of other state universities. 1) 5 references?? 2) How is life around the campus? Looks OK dangerous 3) what does a 'tenure-track-equivalent system' mean? With Floridas eroding of faculty governance and crack down on academic freedom, that sounds like not a secure option 4) sounds like a job to me 5) to be fair, FGCU was tenure-track equivalent since the university was founded and before the recent state-level faculty governance issues. It means you still can, if you wish, go up to associate and full rank, but you won't be let go if you "fail" your tenure application. You could, hypothetically, stay assistant prof until retirement. More flexibility to do whatever you want, and less pressure to appease the senior faculty for tenure purposes. 6) Zoom interview invite! 11/1 x3 7) Any updates? 8) Reached out to the admin specialist on 12/5 and was told that the committee finished the first round of interviews that week, and their goal is to reach out to candidates before the break

column10: 1) The ad mentions that the applicant should "arrange for three reviewers to submit recommendation letters." I added the information for my referees but I do not think the system sent them an automated email already. Does anyone know if this will happen upon submission of the application? In that case, I would have to apply at least a few days before the deadline so that my referees can upload their letters in time. 2) It's hard to tell for sure but usually on a system like this it sends requests as soon as you submit. I would plan for that. 3) The university just put two professors on leave for recent posts. 4) @3, this is still not great, but it does look like one of them was already on medical leave, and the university was deliberately vague about the reason for the leave in the press and didn't actually take action against that prof. 5) SC, any insight on the specific courses this candidate would teach? Upper level or lower level? 6) @1 @2 One of my former students applied to this job and I got an automated email from the university, so I think the system is working. 7) any idea how long the statements should be? No mention of length on the ad. 8) just noticed that "faculty pay ranges are for 8.5 months’ salary", this is weird, right? 9) Does anyone know who the chair of the search is for individuals who might have questions? 10) This question about "what interests you about employment at Syracuse University" is for HR purposes and won't be evaluated by the search committee, right? 11) I mean, it is usually the first question that gets asked in a zoom interview. The text box here is probably just for HR, but it can't hurt to get your answer ready. 10 again) It's not open ended; there are a bunch of boxes to check ranging from "Job Interest Alignment" to "Socially Responsible Organization" to "Retirement Benefits." 11) Question for SC: if we managed to submit our application materials by the 11/30 deadline but SU is still awaiting letters from our referees, will this triage our application or will we be given full consideration in the mean time while our referees submit their letters? 12) full consideration 13) zoom interview request Dec 10 x4 14) dang, how did they get through presumably hundreds of applications in 10 days; 15) Me: ooo. Maybe my invitation got lost in my junk folder! It did not. Ha. x8 16) Assuming they got >100 applicants, I hope the SC understands that asking for rec letters in advance is wasting everybody's time. And please don't tell me SC read all of them by now x2 17) Campus interview invitation 1/8

column10: "address fundamental questions in evolutionary biology utilizing computational approaches and genomic data" 1) What is life like in Laramie, WY? 2) They don't call it Laradise for no reason. Laramie has great outdoor access and suprisingly vibrant cultural scene (more than many towns larger than its size), but it is a small town and can be cold in winter. 3) Laramie is idyllic and absurdly affordable...truly "Laradise". Tons of hiking, biking, climbing, outdoor rec opportunities, adorable farmer's market and downtown scene, really friendly colleagues. Sure, can be cold in winter, but 300+ days of sunshine, so it's cheery and not dreary. Botany and School of Computing are both great departments. This is a cool position. 4) dream location, but not a plant person. There's just way too many plant jobs this cycle! 5) Lived in Laramie for 10 years...colder and windier than nearby Colorado, and a real small town feel; incredibly easy access to hiking, mtn biking, xc skiing, downhill skiing, climbing, rafting, fishing, hunting, and so on, all without crowded trailheads; and university feels like a true community. University went through five presidents 2013-2021, but seems like they've stabilized since then? 6) Great place. Make sure you're okay living somewhere remote. There are almost no towns within a 45-minute radius. 7) @6, but Fort Collins isn't too far away and is a great place to visit! x3 8) UW is doing a presidential search again.  9) Laramie is a wonderful place to live.  Strongly encourage applying, especially if being in a small town with lots of outdoor recreation very close is a draw. 10) fyi they changed the ad yesterday (after the review date) to say that visa sponsorship MIGHT be possible. If you didn't apply for that reason, might be worth sending in an application asap 11) Zoom invite 11/5 x 2 12) @11 anyone hear anything post-Zoom? 13) nothing yet x2 14) 12/17 still no update x2, 12/31/25 still no update 15) Jan 2 - no update yet either. my guess is they won't schedule in person interviews until winter thaws a bit 16) no update 1/27 x2 17) maybe they moved forward with a non eco-evo person 18) yeah, could be

column10: OP) I have been recruited in one such position. Start-up is around 1,5 million euros. They allowed the hiring of 2x 2y postdocs, 2x 4y PhD students and there was plenty of money left for conferences etc. The Museum can be sleepy but we are starting to have regular talks and JCs. We are close to the University in Stockholm, and have regular contact and access to their infrastructure, seminars, etc. TT-to 100% researcher (no teaching obligations). 1) do you want associate professors... this sounds very tempting 2) Just a warning to applicants from outside of Sweden especially Americans* [* discussion of this term removed by consent of those involved -AP], salaries are much lower in Sweden and it should be take into consideration. However, it may be worth it for many since the work life balance is better and salaries are comfortable to afford to live here. OP) Salaries are lower but health and social costs are included. One should read up on the country before applying/considering a move! 2 again) Yes apologies I meant US citiziens since many on the jobboard are from there and many from the US may have interest with moving with recent events. 3) Is this position more focused on computational analysis of existing data (e.g., reference genomes) or would proejcts that entail generating new data that requires extensive computational analysis also fit here as well? 4) @1 "The position is primarily aimed at applicants who have received such a degree no more than eight years before the deadline for applications." so it probably excludes most (not all, maybe) people already in faculty positions :( OP) @3 You should reuse available data/make pipelines, etc, but you can always add new genomes if you want to do comparative work. 5) In reference to @2 and salaries - I was offered one of these positions and the salary that was offered was around 50k euros/60k dollars per year (before taxes). In a major city, do with that information what you will!  5) Is there a timeline for applicants to learn Swedish? 6) Would there be any accommodation for people older than 8 years from PhD if they have had children or other time out in that period? OP) No timeline for learning swedish. 6@ ask people in the search committee directly, but seeing the language of the call, I doubt. 7) Any updates? 8) Any updates? 1/6/26, 9) Any updates 1/15/2026? 10) Any updates 1/26/26? x3 09/02/26, 53 applications currently waiting for the assessment of external reviewers and hope to have reached a decision in April 11) To the above person, did you get an email stating that or are you on the SC?

Areas of expertise may include but are not limited to quantitative ecology, plant sciences, earth sciences, natural resource management, and urban ecology." 1) No research/teaching statements? 2) Geniune question: does $91,922 - $105,593 cover rent in NYC near the college? 3) @2 Of course it depends on how much space you want. And that's why they mentioned public transit on the posting: I'm sure a lot of them commute out of the city or at least other boroughs. 4) Baruch is situated perfectly so you don't have to live in Manhattan. Unless you want to live in a closet you really will not be looking to live close to the college. x2 5) maybe not near the college, but definitely feasible in Manhattan, yes. I live (by myself) reasonably comfortably in Manhattan on a lower salary than that 6) so for this application, is the "required to submit a narrative statement describing their commitment to and experience with working effectively with faculty and staff, and teaching students in a pluralistic urban campus environment with a substantial population of students who are among the first generation of their family to attend a college or university" sort of a mentoring statement addressing both of these points, and no teaching/research statements (echoing @1)? 7) any updates 11/7? 8) Nope! x5 9) Any updates as of 11/18? 10) nope! x4 11/22 11) none 11/30 x5 12) none 12/02 x3 13) none 12/5 x2 14) none 12/11 x4 15) 12/16, still nothing x5 16) 1/5 Zoom interview request x3 17) for the people who received zoom invites, would you be willing to share your general field/area of expertise? 16) Ecosystem ecology/biogeochemistry 17) Seaweed ecology/physiology 18) urban ecology x2 19) No news yet on my side. column10: Would be helpful if this university had been in the news recently so we could evaluate their stance on academic freedom. 2) What "news"? What does this even mean? 3) Firing tenured professors for not aligning with the president's political views. Sad times. 3) Salary Expectations?? 4) to #3, it's a public university so you can see the salaries current professors make in a simple search on google. 5) It is a difficult institution that often is in lock-step with the TX state gov't 6) Somewhat suprised to see an opening for Evolution, wonder if there will be any issues with teaching that? 7) Current faculty here at A&M. Was just teaching evolution last week with no issues. 8) don't come to Texas right now.. just don't. Even if evolution has no issues currently we are all scared. We have students with cellphones actively trying to catch profs in "gotchas" and get them fired. We have multiple faculty under investigation for social media posts or fired for comments at conferences… it's horrific 8) Not sure it really matters, but I think the instructor that was fired was not tenured, or even tenure track 9) I am a recently tenured professor in the dept that is hiring. Yes Texas can be a challenging place to come in the current political climate - that is the clear downside. However, we have many upsides too. This is one of the largest biology departments in the country ~200 grad students ~45 research active faculty, we are building a new biology building/coimplex. We have had zero issues with academic freedom in the sciences. We also have a large and diverse EEB community in our interdepartmental program with about 50 PhD students. School is large enough that resources abound and you can do the science you want and build the lab that you want. I encourage people to apply and then make a decision if you get an interview. We are a fun department that is tight knit and has had a lot of success in the last several years. With regard to comment 8 this is not the landscape in the biology department at all. 10) regarding application documents, are we supposed to have a separate service document? The way it is listed could either be determined as a separate document, or one embedded into the teaching document "short cover letter (one page), curriculum vitae, personal statement to include philosophy and plans for research (max three pages), teaching (max two pages), and service, and contact information for three references" 11) good point 10, the service statment can be included in teaching sorry for the confusing way that we put that sentence. 12) Is it okay to apply after 10/01/25, since the due date is 11/15/25? column10: 60k salary 1) I believe this position was posted twice previously (in fall '24 and spring '25) 2) Anybody knows if min salary is for ABD applicant? 3) @2 not at SUNY Plattsburgh but another SUNY and no, that's the starting salary, and it's pathetic but higher than when I started 4 years ago! wooohoooo, you might be able to get an extra $2-3k in negoations. I was offered $56k at my suny but managed to get them up to $58k lol 3) This kind of thing is what the venting page is for, so that people can vent without annoying the rest of us. 4) Would they consider a hire at the Associate level? 5) @3, this all seems highly relevant for anyone thinking of applying for this job. Scroll past if you don't want to read it. x3 6) @3 very difficult to compare across SUNY campuses because there is a ton of salary heterogeneity (based on research profile and location, the R1 campuses regularly pay 100+ for new assistant profs). Minimum likely means the lower end of the salary band approved internally for the job (I agree that it's likely not to go way higher, but this is worth asking the search chair about down the road rather than making assumptions) 7) Based on the current salaries of their biology assistant professors (https://openpayrolls.com/university-college/suny-plattsburgh), I would not bet on getting a salary offer much higher than that advertised. Also worth noting that the salary increases on promotion are not large. 8) cost of living for a family of 4 in platsburgh is 50K, also a house is under 250K   9)  " teaching undergraduate courses in introductory biology (and associated lab), genetics (and associated lab), cell biology, communicating biology, and courses in the applicant’s areas of expertise." 10) For those saying the salary discussions should be on the venting page, it's very helpful for me to see them here, salary/cost of living can be immediately disqualifying for some of us with dependents/from low income backgrounds. x3 10) I agree salary should be listed, but your mileage may vary on what "liveable" means, because everyone here has a different idea of what that should be. One person's "you can't live on that" is another's "I can make that work". You also don't know what incentives might exist for housing (some schools help faculty with downpayments or have on-campus housing). Utlimately, I think the salary should be shared and people have to do the extra work to see if that pay meets their needs. 11) any updates? x3 12) Phone interview invite 10/7 13) Campus interview invite 10/16 x2 14) Does anyone know if they extended an offer? 15) Yes, they did. column10: Core bioinformatician/computational biologist in the department of Ecology & Evolution to collaborate broadly with department members on projects and grants. This is not a TT position but the previous person in the role retired after 25 years in it. The vision is long term (not a postdoc). 1) European here. Whats life around campus? looks like its in the middle of f nowhere suburbia, with few things else to do than a long drive to Manhattan or Brooklyn? 2) If you think this is the middle of nowhere suburbia you should see the rest of the US! But yeah, deep into Long Island is not a place where everyone is desperate to move to. 3) Definitely suburban, but when you start getting this far out in long island the nature/beaches are also very pretty. A decent number of faculty and many students live in the city (a big chunk of students from queens), but it is a trek. There is a commuter rail that runs to campus but it would be a very long commute. Some people also live in connecticuit and take the ferry as well. @1 4) I've visited long island many times and my partner is from there. If you've never been to the NYC area it is difficult to imagine the size and scale of urbanization and the patterns driven by the development of parkways initially and interstate systems thereafter. It is the original suburban landscape. Stonybrook is on the northshore where I have spent less time and has its own extremely complex geographical history with landowners. Nevertheless, I think you would be deeply impressed by this area. I have been all over the US and there is nothing else like it here. That being said, due to this complex history the traffic is horrible and the rail system has gone through difficult times due to the prioritization of transportation by cars over 1/2 a century. People who live there have adapted to this lifestyle in different ways. 5) Yes, but there are 8 million people on Long Island. It really is not the middle of nowhere. If you want to think about it in European terms it has more people than half the countries in the EU. 6) I did my PhD there, it is honestly a nice area to live relatively speaking, lots of folks communiting into and out of the city, but housing is expensive. 7) Also the area around stony brook is known for having very good schools, but also high taxes 8) life on that part of Long Island can be pretty great - good schools, and more cultural resources than most highly suburban areas across the US - but yeah you are not really close to NYC and I doubt many people that live there work in NY or vice versa. I lived in NY many years and some of my friends commuted to SB - it's 90 minutes to central Queens which is not exactly downtown Manhattan. It's also one of the worst traffic areas in the world (there's only two highways that run east-west). All that is to say if you work at SB you will probably be a Long Islander and not a New Yorker, but there's nothing wrong with that... 8) I work in this department and it's very collegial, good culture. I commute from CTby Ferry which is 3 hrs door to door. My PI commutes from NYC, nearly as long. However, you can read and do other light work while commuting because public transit is good. 9) Three hours?! im so sorry @8... I can barely force myself to commute 10 min 10) for what it's worth, there is housing right next to campus with a <10 min commute, but if you want to live in NYC and have a 10 min commute that's not possible clearlys. 11) any update? 12) Husband got a Zoom interview invite 11/7 13) Second round interview invite 11/23 14) In person interview invite 12/8

Open to all but " Female academics, in particular, are explicitly invited to apply, as are applicants from outside Germany. Applications from equally qualified candidates with disabilities will be given preference." 2) In Germany, positions cannot be advertised as women-only. However, since this one is funded through the Professorinnenprogramm 2030, let’s be realistic, it is effectively limited to women. #) Tubigen is a great small town that has a lot of decent shops and charm. I know a lot of the Profs there are they are all very happy. 4) I confirmed with SC that, since this post is financed from the Professorinnenprogramm for the first 6 years, they can only consider female applicants. [Discussion of gender restrictions deleted. See past years' Venting tabs for the same discussion, over and over again. -AP] 5) No matter how you want to disguise this as DEI, this type of openings are explicitly discriminatory. Sharing this kind of ad just makes you an accomplice in the continuation of this type of discrimination. 6) @5 I'm sorry sir this is a Denny's 7) @5 the program exists to ameliorate existing gender inequality and discrimination in academia; besides, if the opportunity doesn't apply to you, just move on. 8) Invited for interview 9) Congrats @8, wow, that was quick!

column10: Dream job! <3 x2 1) perhaps if you haven't been paying attention to Columbia for the past couple years. 2) @1 Don't apply, move on. x5 3) any details you could reveal for previous negative comments? 1) @3 Columbia has made at least two agreements with the Trump admin to unfreeze $100s of millions in grant money that has involved whitling away academic freedom on campus, including placing some departments under th3e supervision of federal officials, and changing the university's definition of antisemitism to the IHRA definition, which means critising the state of Israel will put you on the wrong side of Columbia's antidiscrimination policies. It has also unwound its DEI policies, and considering how broadly the Trump admin's mass grant freezes have interpreted that, I wouldn't consider applying here if your work touches on even *biological* diversity. https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/mar/21/columbia-university-funding-trump-demands https://www.npr.org/2025/07/25/nx-s1-5479240/columbia-trump-administration-settlement-details 4) Thanks, as an international I will not apply for this. x3 5) More importantly, Columbia (school) is presently being sued by Columbia (sportswear company) for violating their trademark agreement. The school is not to use "Columbia" on its own but they started selling merch with just that (previously they included, by agreement, the founding year or "University"). 6) How is that more important @5? x4 fr! 7) this is all conjecture and gossip, Columbia will be fine x2 8) Currently at Columbia here. It is not fun to see one's institution in the political spotlight and many people are anxious. But wrt actual tangible effects day to day for most people, I do not think it is much different than other R1 institutions heavily dependent on federal funding. It helps that Columbia is a comparatively wealthy school so funds can be moved around. E.g. the university is putting up a substantial amount of bridge funding internally as a direct result of the federal cuts. If you are extremely outspoken politically on social media I would perhaps not recommend applying. And if you are generally not applying to US schools rn that is understandable. But IMO it's not as bad on the ground as you might gather from the media. 9) Thank you @8 for the actually helpful perspective.x5 5) @ 6 because they willfully reneged on a legal agreement and will only lose that case. The other stuff is just pragmatism, agree with it or not. 10) recent post on the Columbia situation from a faculty member: https://www.math.columbia.edu/~woit/wordpress/?p=15286. I couldn't in good conscience consider a job there, but ymmv. 11) @10, then don't and move on 12) Note the job listing says position is contingent on final confirmation of funding 13) I wouldn't read too much into that @12, it's very common. That usually means if they make a hire they will be able to fund it and if they don't make a hire, the university takes the funds back. 14) Anyone having issues with submitting the application on interfolio? 15) Have seen a post from a Department member that priority is given to applications received before Oct 20  16) @14, I had an issue with it saying my application was incomplete even though all of the required files were uploaded. I think this happened because I had the application sitting open for like 20 minutes while I finished creating/saving the last files. Deleting my application and starting over and uploading everything in quick succession did the trick 17) any updates? 18)I havent hear anything (10/21) 19) references requested on 10/22 x5 20) did y'all get emails from interfolio, or were only the references themselves directly contacted? 22) email sent to me and my ref writers via interfolio 23) any updates? 24) none here 11/13 x4 25) I emailed 11/14 about position funding status & response is "not at liberty to say anything concrete about the stage of the search process, but all applicants will receive official word when we have made decisions. " If they are scheduling interviews in early dec surely they would have to let people know ASAP? 25) I know of someone who got an interview on Wedneday, 11/19. So I assume selections are done. 26) thanks @ 25! now I can move on!

column10: 1) See discussion on the need and will to learn and become fluent in french fast to take these jobs and live in Québec/Montréal. It is essential that people learn the language of the country/provice they move to. 2) are candidates who are not already French fluent even considered for these positions? Just curious how that weighs into the selection of a candidate 3) I know an American who worked here and was hired with no French language skills. So it's not impossible. He did indicate that it was pretty hard to teach while just learning French. 4) @2 A good proportion of the latest hires in that department were not francophones.  5) Correct, there are a fair portion of non-Francophones across this, and many other, francophone universities in Québec.what pisses people (francophones) off and what is so excruciatingly hard to understand in this online community is the constant talk of how new TT hires can get away by just continuing speaking *1* language, English, and with as little effort as possible get a TT position in North America without learning the official language. It baffles me daily that people move to our Province without learning French. Imagine moving to Toronto, NYC or San Francisco and insisting on how much it is feasible to live, work, teach, drive a lab while being minimally able to communicate in English while being fluent in French. No way. People: adapt, learn the langauge, speak it and respect that the only, repeast only, offical language in Québec is French. It is exceedingly difficult to do anything Government or Public Administration without being pretty fluent. 6) Gonna push back on 5 here - I'm a historic anglo from QC and the way the government has gone about the language issue from the 60's has done nothing but harm the province. Montreal, in particular, is historically just as much Irish/English as it was French (probably even more so) and the main reason Mtl doesn't have bilingual status is because of fear of reprisals from the province. That said, grad students can write their theses in English at the French schools, and in French at the English schools, but this is all silly as even the most separatist Franco profs do their publishing in English. Bilingualism is always an asset, but using the stick instead of the carrot and further pushing racist/ethnic/linguistic divisions really doesn't help the French language. 7) Please everyone, this is not the place to discuss the political aspect of speaking French vs English in Québec/Montréal. The Université de Montréal is a French-speaking University, and people applying will be expected to teach in French within a few months/years of hiring. They may also have to supervise students that only speak French, so they must be serious about their will to learn the language. Montréal is mostly bilingual, so applicant speaking only in English should be able to live properly when they arrive, and shouldn’t stress about not speaking French on arrival. That’s all applicants need to know. 8) As a Canadian (not Quebecois) with a foreign spouse I am just noticing family sponsorship is closed in Quebec until summer 2026 and they have a limit on the number of applications. Something you may need to navigate if you intend to immigrate to Quebec from outside of Canada. 9) any updates on this one? (11/17) 10) mine still just says application submitted (11/19) 11) In person interviews for this position are starting next week. 12) @11 any more details on this? does that mean for those that still just have no update should assume rejection?

column10: 1) This position will be based in Georgetown, SC at the Baruch Marine Field Lab, not at main campus in Columbia, SC. 2) Two Assistant Professors will be hired from this search. 3) Love this place. If I were at that career stage I'd apply in a heartbeat. 4) Is anyone familiar with lab structure here? Is it primarily PhD students since it's off the main campus and fewer undergraduates or what does that structure look like? x2 5) Small, but ostensibly growing, field lab. In recent history there have been few graduate students in residence, but that is changing. Undergrads come during the summer as interns. Graduate student logistics would depend on what academic dept they're affiliated with on main campus. Field ecologists would have an opportunity to be very productive here given the set up (easy access to field sites, vessel availability, flow-through seawater system, existing long-term datasets and other research infrastructure). 6) Does anybody know what the teaching load and arrangements are? It says there will be some required travel to the main campus in Columbia for teaching. Curious whether they'd want faculty to drive to the main campus regularly to teach undergrad courses. 7) The teaching load isn't set yet, because that will be dependent on which department the hires end up in. But the teaching load for tenure-track faculty in both the School of Earth, Ocean, and Environment and Department of Biological Sciences is 1 class per semester. Having tenure-track faculty based out at the coastal lab is a relatively new thing, so the need to travel to-and-from Columbia is still up in the air and would need to be figured out during negotiations and in the coming year. 8) This job, and others posted this cycle by USC, auto-requests letters of recommendation from listed references. Posting incorrectly states only those selected for virtual interviews will have their references contacted. Beware! 9) Anyone hear anything yet? 10) Nothing here (11/21) 11) Rejection email received 11/25 (no interview) x3 12) No rejection here but also no interview (yet?) 11/26 13) @ 12 same x2 14) invited for Zoom interview 12/1 x3 15) campus invite

column10: [link fixed -AP] 1) so you're telling me my French language skills need to expand beyond "baguette"... okay 2) French is not a requirement to apply but a desire to improve your skills is. The university has a great french immersion program including private tutors to help with the task and non-francophones get 1 year free of teaching to dedicate to learning the language. 3) Is there a French version of the job offer / should people with proficient French language write up their application in French or is English better (considering I'm only finding the English version of the job offer)? 4) the french version is here https://fas.umontreal.ca/public/FAS/fas/Documents/1-faculte_services/poste-professeur/2025/529883_FAS.pdf, but it should (I think) be fine to apply in english—I intend to do that as I have not updated my french CV in 10 years. PS, hoping this is my chance to return to my hometown. 5) you could add a sentence at the end of your first cover letter paragraph in french? Or at the end of the cover letter? I would definately put that you speak french in the cover letter very very clearly 6) would this be typical for other Canadian postings where the cover letter should also include clear mention of citizenship? 7) Same question as 6, I'm confused with "responsible citizens" does that mean only Canadain citizen are eligible? If not, is there any visa support. x2 8) Its not restricted to Canadian citizens and yes the university offers a lot of support to foreign hires including visas 9) I cannot see the deadline to apply on the ad; is it 10/19/2025 as it appears on the spreadsheet? [link updated, which includes deadline -AP] 6) Do we know if letters are required up front? 10) I was about to submit my application but the portal says the position is no longer available. Is this true? 11) Same deal here, job not available. It seems ot me like an issue with the portal (probably submission Sunday 19 defaults to Friday 17 by the end of the day). I will contact the chair directly so they're aware of the issue and strike myself out of the search in doing so :D. Good luck 12) I had a similar problem and realized i needed to log in, create an account, the portal is a bit glitchy 13) any updates? 14) nothing here 4/11 x12 15) Any updates? 12/11 16) Non. x5 17) moi non plus (16 novembre) x6 (19 novembre) x8 (24 novembre) x7 18) Invited for in-person interview (28 Nov) 19) Congrats to those who got an interview—I thought I had a shot at this one but it must be an impressive shortlist. 20) @18: Congrats! I assume you were invited on 27th, not 28th? (According to the "last update" column you wrote on Nov 27th). Anyone else here received an invite? 20) Congrats to those invited. I also thought I stood a shot but I guess not... onto more applications! x2 21) They received 132 applications for this position, and invited 3 for on-campus interviews. You are all excellent, the fit just wasn't perfect (except for 18) :) Bonne chance pour vos prochaines applications X2 ! 22) For those who haven't been invited to the interviews (so...129 of us haha), did you ever receive an email ? Just trying to make sure I didn't miss anything. Thanks ! 23) I did not receive an email, but I think usually, they do not send out rejection emails until they have an accepted job offer. But maybe you were asking about emails confirming receipt of applications—i did not get one of those either and definitely submitted mine before the deadline.

column10: The successful candidate will be expected to teach three courses each semester, with one of those courses being an offering in Molecular Ecology. Starting $53k. 1) they expect 30% research time with 6 courses a year?! along with that salary, oh my woof. 2) I'm from that area - it's a low salary comparatively, but southern Louisiana is a low cost of living area. 3) this salary make me feel sad and insulted at the same time. 4) as someone living in southern Louisiana, this salary is less than what I make as a postdoc. I wouldn't touch this job with a 10 foot pole. 5) Great food, cool Cajun culture, but hurricane prone and exorbitant insurance and sales tax rates.6) The teaching load and pay makes this feel a bit predatory if you are expected to take your research seriously. Whether they intended it or not, they are capitolizing on a candidate pool of desperate PhDs in a scarce market. I know the faculty has their hands tied to some degree, but these people are suppose to be your colleagues. I wish they would fight harder to treat the upcoming generation better. Sorry, this should be in the "venting" tab. 6)(again) I thought I was on the postdoc tab or it was a VAP. This is a TT job!? Ridiculous! 7) Eeesshh...wish I could downvote this job ad. 8) This uni used to pay ~35K USD annually for lecturers that would teach multiple sections of a course 9) Nicholls is a generally impoverished university when it comes to biology

column10: 1) "Prioritized focal areas include abiotic stress tolerance for drought, cold, heat, or salinity stress in ornamentals, turf, woody species, or crops relevant to semi-arid or high-elevation regions. Both basic and applied approaches, including model systems, are welcome." 2) dream university for me, but alas not a plant biologist :( 3) dream university location for sure. $78 - $80K salary though is not a dream.  2 again) will be more than happy with 70k or less if I get to live in Montana for the rest of my life. 4) I hear you. I'm going to apply but in Bozeman the "average home prices well over $800,000 and rent typically between $1,900–$2,800", make it like I'll probably have to have a side hustle too.  5) II wonder if general plant ecology too far afield for this one? 5) Current MSU faculty (not on SC); I would still view base salaries (and everything) as negotiable in this case, startups (historically) come with summer salary support to get you going, and 800K is more applicable to standalone 2K square foot homes. The market has cooled, and there are a variety of housing types probably starting in the ~400Ks, but I can't argue that the imbalance of salary to housing costs is the #1 problem at MSU (and bozeman) and I've been dissapointed at the shoulder shrugs from admin about it. 6) Just finished graduate degree at MSU-- great location for sure, but I cannot stress enough that you should visit and make sure you're willing to live in an expensive mountain town with cold winters. It was great for me, but seriously consider the housing market and lifestyle. 7) I love cold winters. @6 how was the grad student support? It sounds like you survived--congrats, but if they pay starting professors a postdoc salary how do they pay grad students and postdocs there? Looking up the salaries at MSU is interesting, some decent salaries across departments, but the assistant profs in this department look rediculously low ($50K?), if accurate.  8) You can expect probably at least 80K base, 50K is wrong or outdated, especially for this type of position. Summers are short and glorious but activity-wise it really is a winter (and therefore ski) dominant town. For student support, you have to be scrappy at MSU and therefore be able to acquire internal and external funding and do so creatively. GTA support is nowhere near a UGA or Madison; Montana is a poor state, but that also opens up less-competitve EPSCoR pools of $. 9) MSU is not hiring researchers they need to sponsor visa/green card, I know from someone that recently applied for a position there. 10) Hi this is 6 responding-- the department I was in was great and I lived in on campus housing. I was able to TA every semester that I wanted and was a GRA every semester also. I had no financial support from my family or side jobs and I had enough for rent and fun stuff-- wasn't gonna travel to Disney and buy designer clothes but I could maintain my hobbies and eat and have a car. The LRES department at MSU pays grad students better than a lot of the departments on campus because we publish a lot--I've heard department of Ecology isn't as good but is still better than others. Grad student housing rent just went up by something stupid like 30% though and they're not allowed to increase grad student pay by more than 5% (this is if memory serves, I might be wrong). Grad student support was great, love the GSO, and the profs (mostly). Frankly I preferred it to the bigger R1 I'm at now for a postdoc where everyone is cold and hostile and socially awkward. 11) Recently hired MSU faculty (not in this department): my experience was that the academic year salary was not negotiable outside of the published salary band for the position I applied to. Other components were negotiable, but salary really was not. And yes Bozeman is expensive especially relative to the university salary. Grad student support varies by department (for example, how GTA vs GRAs work), and is a good thing to ask about during on campus interview IMO. 12) what is it like being a queer in Boseman and latina?

column10: 1) Position type listed here as non-tenure stream, and the posting says "This is a full-time, continuing faculty position on a 10-month contract in an extended contract system." I'm new to the game...can someone please explain what this means? Is tenure ever possible in this position? How long are these "extended contract" appointments for, generally speaking? Thanks! 2) Warren Wilson doesn't do tenure at all, so all faculty are on these extending contracts. They start off shorter and as you get more senior, they get longer. The idea is that these are long term positions, there's just no tenure 3) "Preferred expertise in hydrology, soil science, or biogeochemistry." 4) @3 (or anyone), how often is this super super critical? I study none of those, do I even stand a chance? Does that depend on the applicant pool? 5) @4 I would say it's probably not the best use of your time if they specifically mention those fields. If there is a search chair listed, you could email them (or even try emailing dept chair, which will be public info) to ask. But I suspect they will get plenty of applicants who do study those preferred fields. 6) @5 will they though? In my experience as a current assistant prof who has been on the market a few cycles and others I've talked to, sometimes the searches that were most interested in me were either not what they were initially looking for and/or a slight stretch from what I would typically categorize myself as. Do with that as you will, but sometimes it doesn't hurt to shoot your shot (when it's realistic) 7) That's also a pretty narrow set of fields at an unusual school that has had financial issues, so I wouldn't be surprised if they don't have a huge applicant pool even with the current market. x2 8) Survey after submission indicates starting point for salary is likely to be around $59k. 9) Seconding what (8) says. Survey states "The salary for this position is budgeted for $59,000 per year, with limited room for negotiation for exceptional qualifications." 10) any updates? 11) none here as of 11/3 11) Virtual interview request received on 11/4

column10: 1) TVL e13 is basically postdoc salary (3000 E net per month on level 1 which most foreigners will get) 2) Where they can put you in e13 can be negotiated. I also think for an head of department you can really make a case for e14. You would not be put at level 1 for this position because if you were, you are not qualified for the position because e13 level is years worked based. The main reason why many foreigners get put at level 1 is that they were paid by bursary during their phd or they do not negotiate the level. 3) As a German myself I've seen this multiple times. E14 is after evaluation and nothing close to a W1, W2 or W3...4) have experience in working with non-model organisms (animals), 4) review date here is 9/30 but on the job ad it says "Centre for Molecular Biodiversity Research should be submitted no later than October, 7th 2025 only digitally to Andreas Pfeifer.". Can anyone confirm? 5) @4 I can confirm that when I printed a pdf of the page two weeks ago, deadline was Septmber 30th! They probably changed it because they did not get enough applications?! 4 again) I emailed the SC and they confirm the deadline has been pushed to Oct 7 6) Invited to interview (on zoom) 12/3 7) Congratulations, good luck @6! 8) Got an email that position was  filled 1/14

column10: 1) Does this job include advising graduate students of any sort? I see that it is primarily undergraduate but there are graduate programs in science - any context is appreciated 2) Very unlikely. The grad programs are in the two graduate-only colleges, and the colleges comprising this department are not primarily undergraduate but solely undergraduate. Your primary duty will be teaching, mentoring, and advising the undergrads, and your research program may be able to accomodate a postdoc, should you get the money for one, but not a gradaute student of your own. No one will stop you from being on a graduate committee somewhere else or even co-advising, but for RPT purposes it may not "count", so it would be in addition to, not in lieu of, your primary responsibilities. @2) thank you so much, that information is very helpful! x 2 3) starting salary 100K-110K.
