column10: Two positions, part of a cluster hire for the new Center for Comparative Genomics. Four thematic areas: vertebrate/arthropod genomics, developmental genomics, biodiversity & conservation genomics, structure and function of complex genomic regions. 2) Can anyone share what life is like around campus? It looks like its a bit in the middle of nowhere. 3) Interviewed here for a postdoc, it felt like a small college town with extensive ROTC presence (saw tons of people in their military uniform on campus). You'll see tons of ranches 15 minutes outside of the town. Didn't end up choosing this place (chose Colorado instead). 4) Very isolated but the community is good, as long as you don't mind 2+ hour drives to the nearest city 5) @3 The Corps of Cadets is unlike any ROTC with more than half of them not actually in ROTC. Having done my PhD there, it's not a bad place but is a different feel from most colleges (though not faculty--those are pretty much the same everywhere). 6) @4, the Bryan-College Station metro has over 250,000 people. 7)@6, Out of which roughly 1/3 are affiliated with TAMU, and then you're 2.5 hrs away by car from any city, without many public transit options to get there. Nothing wrong with small towns with a big college, but they aren't vibrant metropolitan areas..... 6 again) OK yeah I agree with that. I grew up in a corn field so College Station feels large, vibrant, diverse. Nothing like nearby Houston and Austin, though. 8) FYI, this didn't happen in Biology, but worth knowing about the campus climate and leadership: https://www.chronicle.com/article/a-classroom-clash-over-course-content-went-viral-texas-a-m-fired-the-instructor-and-removed-2-administrators. Any update? 9) email from HR that they are not going with applicants who need visa sponsorship on 10/2. 10) in- person interview on 10-10 from the companion CCGEN search in vet/med (x2). 11) additional info on the companion CCGEN search in vet/med would be appreciated! 12) Got an email about in-person interview from the vet/med dept on 10/20. column10: Any american could clarify this? Generous leave package which includes sick, vacation (staff only), and personal leave; 13 paid holidays; paid medical maternity and parental leave 2) What kind of clarification are you looking for? The description is a bit vague but that's not unusual. 3) I did not understand if the person is only entitled to 13 days of pay holidays per year. 4). That means that 13 days are automatically granted as "vacation", but you would accrue additional vacation days as well.  So it's not only 13 days off the whole year, but 13 + some amount.  Often times that "some amount" starts out at two weeks (or maybe three) and the longer you work there the more discretionary days off you get.  The 13 paid holidays are things like Christmas, New Year's day, labor day, Thanksgiving Thurs+Fri, etc. 4) 13 days + "Christmas, New Year's day, labor day, Thanksgiving Thurs+Fri, etc" is considered generous? Eh.. 5)The 13 paid holidays are those things. It's not clear how much other time off is granted. x2 6) This is typically negotiated as its a staff position (its usually not bad at all). Staff get off most of the academic breaks as well. OP) Applications are still open but we are starting to formally review in the next week (9.16.25).

column10: 1) 70-80% of working time is expected to be spent assisting and facilitating (long-term and daily) researchers from the Swedish Museum of Natural History who want to conduct collection-based genetic research. 20-30% is expected to be devoted to own research, which includes publishing research articles and applying for external funding. 2) Since the job ad is in Swedish, is it safe to assume that the job requires advanced skills in it to qualify? 1) Do you mean advanced Swedish skills,2)? The department for Genetics and Bioinformatics has all communication in English community and you will do well without Swedish. However, the HR-realm is still very Swedish, as reflected on this job application. For your day-to-day work you will do fine without Swedish. 3) Yes, you *can* do well without Swedish fluency, but just as with moving anywhere new: learn the language, take the time and the integration and connection with locals with improve dramatically. Imagine moving to a US or anglophone Canada university for a similar position and barely being able to speak english, but only Spanish or French. In Sweden, we really appreciate people taking the time and effort to learn. We dont expect people to speak fluently, but showing effort goes a long way. I can guarantee you that any SC will ask questions on your willingness to try and learn. 4) Job description in English https://recruit.visma.com/spa/public/apply?guidAssignment=b487185a-a45b-4f0b-b6ee-e282ad731b66&publishCode=AMS&TK=e3a2d3a0-5820-4bf5-9e8a-a8cc11ed88e9

column10: lol AS IF rockefeller is going to hire an organismal biologist 1) um the Vertebrate Genomes Project is housed there 2) And the clonal raider ant lab is thriving there. Enough with the negative conjecture please. x5 3) With Rockefeller being an R2, does anyone have any idea about the balance of research vs teaching expectations? 4) I'm a plant bio postdoc and I know Rockefeller housed Nam-hai Chua for many years. It's a great research facility although I don't know much about teaching load. I think 'R2' doesn't really matter. (Actually surprised Rockefeller is R2.) 5) The only reason it's an R2 is because it's so small. Those classifications are based on total grants and PhDs awarded. 6) Rockefeller has interviewed a number of highly talented organismal biologists in recent years so don't count yourself out (though the standards there are incredibly high.) There is 0 teaching requirement. 7) Based on the job ad it is pretty clear they are leaning MD/PhD and probably want more medically focused research 8) It's Rockefeller. It's not about if you do ecoevo but if your output is really great. Yes, I guess your output should overwhelm those from MD/PhD. 9) They post this same open call job ad every single year. I don't think they are 'leaning' any particular way, they are just fishing for people publishing CNS papers with big grant streams. x2 10) I thought Rockefeller did medical research- do they also support basic science without direct health implications? 11) yeah, Rockefeller (and many other medial institutes) have rich histories of fundamental mol/cell biology research on weird non-model creatures 12)Any updates? 13) None here X2 14)No updates 4/11 x4 15) no word 16) one of my letter writers let me down. am I screwed? 16) Any updates? so far nothing on my end (november 16th) x3 17) Rejection 11/20 (x1 international) x5 18) Rejection email on the 15th of Dec. after zoom (applied under organismal Bio) x 2 19) also rejected after zoom for the OBE subcommitte, but still felt good about the conversations. I hope they do *real* search for an organismal biologist someday :P

column10: 1) Can someone from the SCHOOL please expand on this essential requirement: "Knowledge of how to provide sympathetic pastoral care to students at all levels."? What do they mean by "pastoral care"? 2) I am not from the SC, but I've seen this phrase used elsewhere in other institutions. I think it basically means that if you notice a student in distress, you have an idea of how to support them and can at least try helping them get through it 3) British lecturer here (but not at this uni) - most undergraduates at UK unis will be assigned a 'pastoral tutor',  'personal tutor' or similarly-named person, usually an academic involved in their degree. Expectations will vary, but you usually meet each tutee once or twice per semester to make sure they're on track and generally happy in life. If they have problems that require special attention then you can direct them to counselling, finance teams, etc. You also write their reference for jobs/grad school, should they ask for one. Basically, it's about caring for students beyond reading lists, classes and examinations, and depending on their choice of classes you may never actually teach your tutees. Tutor training is usually given, to make sure you ask the right questions when you're concerned about someone. It isn't the biggest part of the job, but it's very important and very rewarding. 4) It's similar to being a "faculty mentor" with assigned undergrads (many US universities have this system). 5) Did anyone go to the open information session and was there anything useful mentioned at it? I was in another meeting that day and missed it sadly! x2 6) I was there. They will do a long-listing process to initially screen a larger group of potential candidates, which will need to give a short (12 min) online presentation between 17-28th Nov; those that are short-listed will told 'immediately' (not sure how immediate) and called back for a longer online interview (10 min presentation, 30 min structured interview) between 8-12th Dec. Expected to start by September 2026 but as early as April; campus location largely dictated by research area; internal PhD scholarships should be available to new recruits but not 100% guaranteed. They anticipate that they will announce the long-listed candidates by November 7th. 7) I'm confused, do they just want a CV and a cover letter or do they want full research/teaching/EDI statements to fit in the 4000 word boxes? 8) They ask for a teaching statement in the list of what to include in the CV but they don't mention DEI or research statements. They're less common for UK positions from what I've seen. In the information session they said they were interested to see how people filled in the text boxes but they didn't have a specific way they wanted them filled. Not sure if adding a research statement would be an asset or hindrance, though. 9) anyone knows when we can expect to hear about the long-listing selection? or has anyone already heard back from the SC? 10) In my experience UK searches are typically pretty good about informing all applicants about their status at each step. So if you haven't heard anything, I'm guessing no one has. x2 11) UK searches typically go quick ime. I would guess that interview invites are going out soon, if they haven't already 12) At the presentation they said they expected to send out invitations by November 7th.  It may be earlier than that, but I personally am not expecting to hear anything until then.10) Thanks for the info, 12! x2 13) Has anyone logged into the application system? When I do, it shows me having two applications for this job, one of which appeared a week or so after I applied. 14) Just checked. Same as 13. Strange! 15) I have another application started a week later also but mine is for the life sciences stream I applied for specifically. Was that the same for others? 16) It is now Nov 7, has anyone heard? 17) No news. x5 18) they are currently moving forward with interviews. rejection letters will go out when the search has concluded. 19) For a similar position last year, they sent rejection letters about a month after the review date (I had applied back then too). I guess they won't do it this time? 19) Looks like all applicants just got an email saying they will invite folks for interviews until the 14th 20) Did anyone else not receive that email just now? 21) Email says they had 550 applications 22) my understanding is that this was sent to all applicants, including those who were offered an interview, no? because they say next step will be for applicants invited to give a seminar. sounds to me like it's for the few ones who made it through the interview stage.  23) It sounds like they haven't actually sent out interview invites yet?  No one on here at least has gotten an interview invite? x4 24) I got that email and did not receive an interview invite yet so it seems like they sent it around widely x2 25) Zoom invite 11/13 x4 26) Does anyone have the ad saved that they would be willing to share since it's no longer posted? 27) found it here: https://www.jobs.ac.uk/job/DOI465/assistant-associate-professors 28) which area/stream did you all apply to, who got zoom invites? 11/13 Zoom invite 29) @28 T&O + M&C 30) Anyone from the ecology stream? 31) @30 me! x2 32) post-Zoom rejection x4

column10: 4 positions. 1) One of the greatest resources here for the right person would be OKEON (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c4T8Q58mvMI), but at present its future is a bit uncertain. It could be worth mentioning if you think this network would be valuable to you. 2) What is start up funding like? 3) Usually fairly generous, and one of the strengths of an OIST position is that it comes with ongoing high-trust funding so you have an annual lab budget that is enough to run a decent sized lab even before competitive funding. It is not quite the money fountain it used to be but it is still very generous compared to most places. 4) Additionally, the costs of hiring postdocs and technicians are covered by a separate budget, and PhD students are fully funded by the graduate school. 5) Any thoughts on how long the engagement statement could be? 6) letters to be uploaded by 10/15...? No contact information listed 7) @5, I imagine 2-3 pages as a good rule of thumb maybe? @6, probably just safest to assume letters have the same deadline 8) I wonder if they will have medium-list zoom pre-interviews like US searches. column10: One of the search committee members confirmed that this position is intended for candidates with expertise in biochemistry, genetics, and plant biology, with research that clearly integrates ecological and/or evolutionary perspectives. In particular, the role focuses on the biochemical and molecular ecology of plants to understand how ecological dynamics drive plant adaptation, species interactions, and ecosystem function. 1) Yes, this position is a replacement for Dr. Jeeyon Jeong, who recently passed away. 2) Note from a member of the department: expertise in plant biology is desirable because that area is underrepresented in our department, but it is not a requirement of the position.  Please also note that this is a completely open search; rumors that this is a sham search for an internal candidate are false.  Interested applicants are encouraged to contact the department chair with any questions. @2) Thank you for the clarification, and appreciate your clear statement that the search is open and not intended for a pre-selected internal candidate, which should help close the door on such rumors. 3) Not liking the drift towards a world in which search committees are routinely expected to debunk baseless speculation about preferred internal candidates for US and Canadian jobs. A better norm would be to scold the people who start and spread those rumors, or for AP to delete all such rumors. We shouldn't be indulging conspiratorial thinking x2. @3 Did you read 1’s and 2’s responses first? #1 clearly stated that this position is a replacement for a plant biologist. #2, apparently from the department itself, confirmed that plant biology expertise is “desirable.” Yet nowhere in the official job description is plant biology listed as desired or preferred. That means only internal candidates would realistically know what the hiring committee is prioritizing, which creates an uneven playing field for external applicants. What does this tell you? 4) Honestly, the only conclusion I can draw from the nonsense in #3’s response is that #3 is very likely the internal candidate themselves, or at the very least someone with a vested interest in shutting down this discussion. x5 3) You've solved the great conspiracy. Well done. x2 6) I am concerned that some are treating these issues lightly, when in fact they raise very serious questions about fairness and transparency in academic hiring.Transparency requires that all applicants—internal or external—have access to the same criteria and expectations. When “desirable” qualifications are left unstated, it undermines the integrity of the process. Dismissive responses that frame these concerns as “conspiracy thinking” only reinforce the perception of bias. Rather than shutting down discussion, departments should take such concerns seriously, since accountability and openness are central to equitable hiring. We should keep our eyes on the outcome of this hire. If the result aligns with the unofficial criteria rather than the official posting, it will confirm the very inequities being raised here and should be flagged for closer scrutiny. 6) #3 here. Lol, I don't work at Amherst, never have. Not even a current job seeker. Looking forward to accusations that I'm an internal candidate who's lying to scare away external applicants. @3 I believe no one here is interested in confirming whether you are or aren’t the internal candidate, that’s irrelevant. What is relevant is why someone who claims not to be a job seeker is nonetheless monitoring and commenting repeatedly on a specific job posting, pushing the same dismissive line each time.. If you truly have no stake in this hire, then your repeated interventions look less like neutral observation and more like an attempt to dismiss legitimate concerns. 7) #3 again. There's your problem--you're assuming the comments you don't like are all from me. They're not. And the repeated baseless rumors that crop up on this sheet about sham searches intended for favored internal candidates are toxic paranoia, not "legitimate concerns". x2 8) Easy, dude. #3, what are you even saying? You’ve been repeating the same line over and over, nobody cares who you are. The issue is transparency in the hire. And if you’re not currently looking for jobs, as you’ve said, then why keep pushing so hard on this one posting? Dudes #1 and #2 already laid out the key facts, this is about fairness, not conspiracy. 9) #2 here: I apologize if my previous statement about plant biology expertise being "desirable" indicated any sort of hidden agenda in the search. We are a small department trying to cover the breadth of biology, so any area of expertise or model system that is not currently represented or underrepresented in our department would be considered desirable. 3) I hope you actually give that internal candidate a fighting chance. It is really demoralizing if they are a fantastic scientist and colleague but are nervous in the interview and as a result do not get selected. Been there done that. Good luck to whomever the internal candidate may be. And no I am not it but I am an internal candidate somewhere else and interviewing with people you share jokes with everyday is nerve-wracking. 11) @3 The issue here isn’t about whether an internal candidate “gets a fighting chance.” Internal candidates already benefit from familiarity, access, and visibility that external applicants simply don’t have. That’s not demoralizing—it’s an inherent advantage. What is demoralizing is when job postings appear tailored in timing or criteria to match the profile of one or two insiders, which discourages highly qualified external candidates from even applying. That undermines the spirit of an open and competitive search. Searches at institutions like Amherst College should be about finding the best possible candidate for students and the department’s future, not about managing interview nerves for someone who already had insider access. If the process is fair, then the strongest applicant—internal or external—should rise to the top. 3) Assuming that familiary is advantageous is a mistake. It actually can make it harder and we all know that regardless of how good you have been and are and will be as a scientist, a simple 1 or 2 day interview, or worse a 20 min zoom can negate all of that if your nervousness makes you make a little mistake. Being an internal candidate is actually pretty awful. Most people are good enough. It is not about who is the best. And in that sense internal candidate is actually the best for the employer because there is less training and other crap to take care of because of familiarity. The truth is most candidates that were short-listed will do just fine job so making an offer to the internal candidates makes the most sense. @3 That line of reasoning might feel valid from the inside like yourself, but it sidesteps the fundamental purpose of a national search: to ensure that faculty hires are based on merit, vision, and future promise—not familiarity or convenience. Yes, interviews are stressful. Yes, anyone—internal or external—can stumble. But the solution isn’t to lower the bar or reward proximity. It’s to make sure the process is equitable, robust, and transparent so that everyone, including those who’ve never had the chance to “share jokes in the hallway,” has a fair shot. ,And no, internal candidates are not “the best” for the employer just because they’re easier to onboard. That mindset reduces hiring to a logistical shortcut, not a strategic investment in academic excellence. Faculty searches aren’t just about who’s “good enough.” They’re about finding the best fit for long-term educational and scholarly impact. 12) can you all please save your useless arguing for the venting tab and leave this space for job related discussion? 13) Were recommendation letters due right away? 14) Any updates? 15) Nopes x4 16) Anyone invited for 1st interview? 17) Not that I'm aware of x5 18) Sham search for an internal candidate as mentioned above? 19) I'm guessing the delay is because they have 2 concurrent searches. 20) Zoom invite 10/6 x2 20) Onsite invite 10/20 x2 21) Has anyone heard anything after the onsite interview? 20) Nothing, guessing an offer is out and we didn't get it 21) Yes, that's what I'm thinking too. It would have been amazing! 20) Absolutely the dream job

column10: 1) "This search is particularly aimed at identifying early career scholars who show exceptional promise. We especially encourage applications from individuals who have recently completed a PhD, or who are nearing completion of such a degree at the time of application" -- seems weird?? 2) doesn't seem that weird to me to encourage that. They want to scoop up the best before someone else does, but people fresh out of or still in school would be hesitant to apply to a job at STANFORD, thinking they have no shot. I certainly felt that way with certain dream postings. This lets such applicants know the SC is truly open to giving someone like that a shot. What's weird is when a posting caps the age of applicants, in order to encourage early-career researchers to apply (vs putting a cap on the number of years since defending). 3) @ 2 - I don't see any mention about age. Early-career =/= young (as someone who started their PhD @ 30yrs old) ... 4) any interviews yet? 5) @4, 10/31 haven't heard anything. x7 6) @4 11/17 haven't heard anything x4  7) 11/18 zoom interview invite  8) Rejected x5 9) 12/12 campus interview invite x2. 10) 12/17 Rejected. x2 11) any updates? has an offer gone out? 12) offer has gone out

column10: What's this department like? 1) search co-chair here. We're an integrative biology department with faculty who study everything from ecosystem ecology to stem cell biology. The ecology and evolution faculty (and other faculty) are collegial and enthustiastic. 2) It's a generally cordial department. Not as much socializing as other places (probably because most folks need to drive home after work), but the ecology faculty seemed pretty friendly when I was there. 3) I did my PhD in this department, really great faculty and supportive department with $$$, some higher ups have catholic conservative motivations that can interfere with good science/hiring/retention x2 4) Also worth mentioning that the cost of living in South Bend is very low, nice houses under 100K - even grad student stipends go a long way. 5) Any idea of what it's like being gay/in an openly and visually queer marriage at Notre Dame and South Bend in general? x2 6) ND has a LGBTQIA+ employee resource group called Spectrum for queer faculty and staff, which has been a good network for me at the university. I had no issues within the Biology Dept (I was staff), but feel free to reach out to Spectrum directly to ask for more conversations or perspectives. 7) I see that the job description states that "successful candidates will engage with and benefit from UNDERC (...)". Does this imply that they are only considering applicants who will be tailoring their research program to work in this NEON field station? 8) search co-chair again, engaging with UNDERC is definitely not a requirement, but I can see why the wording is confusing. Rather, we were trying to highlight UNDERC and other facilities as possible benefits of ND to scientists who can make logical use of them in their programs. 9) Are references immediately contacted? 10) References are not contacted immediately. We will contact references at the Zoom interview stage. 11) @10 Great, thank you for the information! 12) @SC members: any preference or recomemndation on # of pages for research statement: 2 pages or 3 pages? 13) @12 we have no preference. Take what you need to explain your program. 2or 3 pages is fine. 14) is deadline 10/15 or 10/27? highered vs interfolio say different things. 15) @14 Oct 27th is the final deadline, but we will start looking at applicarions on the 15th. 16) @3 LMFAO, they are far from supportive. I've known over 6 people pursuing PhD in Evolutionary Biology that left without their degrees within the last 8 years because of the faculty, three (NOW 4) of which were from the same lab. 17) Any updates? x8 18) I am a graduate from the PhD program - 3  people leaving from the same lab says more about the faculty member they were working with! Excellent school with $$$$! 16) @18 the fact the admins and upper level folks are fully aware of the person's rep and won't do anything and another prof had multiple formal allegations but retired "early" with full pension and honor intact and zero accountability. 19) Unfortunately 16, that pattern wouldn't be at all unique to this department. Basically some version of that story could be told everywhere I've ever spent time, the difference is just in how widely known the details are. (x2) 20) any updates on this search - has anybody had their references write letters already? 21) no, not here x15 22) 54 applicants via ecoevojobs is craazy - most of any job in the past two cycles on this board! 23) Any updates 11/18? x5 24 @22 I guess people aren't afraid of red states... 25) surely they have lots of applications to sift through but this is taking quite a bit longer to get to their Zoom interview stage than other apps i've been involved with 26) my guess is they are overwhelmed and have to rethink their process. anybody from SC here to clarify? 27) I had letters requested. Not sure when exactly but I think just this week. Request went to my writers not to me. 28) Letters requested yesterday (11/24). 29) Very cool to request letters from people the day before many of them take off for the holidays (in the States). 30) Letters requested (11/24) x5 30) Think some letter requests may be going out piecemeal, as some of my refs got requests and some did not. 31) anyone know what they mean by 'multiple' positions - are we talking 2 positions, 3, or more? How big is the cluster? 32) Wording is intentionally vague. 33) My guess is that the SC will interview around 15 to 20 people on Zoom, bring 6 to 9 to campus, and hire about 2 to 3 in the end. 34) Zoom invite 12/1 x4  35) Weird that they would start sending out zoom invites before the deadline for letters to be submitted, no? 36) I would assume they plan to use letters + zoom interviews to decide on campus invites and they want to get zooms done before holiday breaks start. 36) Seems pretty standard to pair zoom interviews and letter requests. Not unusual for me to receive a Zoom interview even before letter requests go out. 37) Interesting tidbit is that Zoom invite email stated they received >400 applications for these positions! The number of ppl who said they applied here on this board is 55, so around one-eighth of the total applicants 38) Also based on the number of initial open zoom times and the number left now it looks like they scheduled about 15-20 candidates for zoom meetings. 39) Anyone else had their letters requested but did not receive zoom interview? x3 40) ND undergrad alum here, I didn't hear anything about letters being requested, and haven't seen any information about zoom interviews, but received an offer for a TT position elsewhere, is it even worth me trying to reach out to the SC? Just don't want this "what if" following me around for the rest of my life 41) I can't imagine what you would gain by contacting them 40. 42) @#41 True, just delusional hope I could leverage my current offer 43) at 42, yeah, if you did not get a Zoom interview I don't think there's any way to move forward 44) Anyone get a campus invite? I thought they would have gone out by now. 45) No news on my end 12/17 x 3 46) Invited for campus interview 12/18 47) Rejection received 12/22 x2 48) Did anyone who zoomed but didn't get a campus invite get a rejection? 49) zoomed but did not receive a campus invitation or a rejection. x 4  50) Has an offer been made? x2 51) I hear two offers have been made for this search.

column10: "Preference will be given to applications from individuals whose country of residence and current appointment/employment is outside of Canada at the time of nomination; however, strong applicants currently employed in Canada will also be considered.  Applicants currently employed in Canada must demonstrate how moving from their current institution to the University of Guelph will result in a net benefit to Canada...Candidates must be full professors (or equivalent) or associate professors who are expected to be promoted to full professor within one or two years of the nomination." Application reviews start on September 1, but the applications will close on October 3. Canada Excellence Research Chair. 1) The CERC part should be at the top. Pretty stringent requirements. 2) I heard that these positions are primarily given to DEI candidates based on Canadian govt requirements. Is this true? 3) @2 it varies a lot but the job ad will explicitly say if they are targetting specific groups that are underrepresented in some aspect of the CRC/CERC pool. 4) @ 2 Those are the Tier 2 CRC (Canada Research Chairs). The Canada Excellence Research Chairs are aimed at developing research hubs, not EDI targets. 5) note that the deadline has been updated to October 6th [updated -AP] [rank updated to Assoc / Full -AP] 6) received email informing that application has passed to next round 10/21 x2

column10: "We seek an exceptional researcher to join the leadership team of one of the CLO’s major programmatic centers, the Macaulay Library, and pursue an interdisciplinary research program using the analysis of large datasets of digital media. Research areas may include, but are not limited to, animal behavior, ecology, conservation biology, global change ecology, computational biology, or evolution, particularly, but not exclusively, in avian systems." Accepting applications until filled. Apps before review-by date get priority. Doesn't have to be bird research, but it is The Lab of Ornithology  2) Ithaca is a wonderful place to live and the Lab of O is awesome. 3) !'Doesn't have to be bird research'! It would be too funny to have a bat lab in that department :P 4) @3, there is a ton of bioacoustics research at CLO that is not on birds. Probably the majority of the acoustics researchers actually. It has a long history of whale research plus elephants, insects, etc. 5) Yang Center for Conservation Bioacoustics basically is everything except birds, from what I can see 6) The Lab of O is awesome, but Ithaca gets 150ish days of sunshine/year (we lived there for 2 years... most days are gray and it gets a bit depressing, even with those UV lamps!) 3) The listing says Assistant professor, yet here the rank is Assoc/ Full Prof. 4) @3 I see Assoc / Full 6) Lab of Ornithology employee here: they are definitely looking for someone at the Associate Professor level. Highly likely that they want a behavioral ecologist, large datasets, birds preferably. 7) did someone get hired?

column10: See here for some background and additional info from a dept member: https://dynamicecology.wordpress.com/2025/08/08/tenure-track-asst-professor-of-freshwater-ecology-at-the-university-of-calgary-please-apply/. In particular: no, the short deadline does not mean it's intended for an internal candidate. No reference letters required up front. Open to non-Canadians. 2) Should we interpret 'freshwater ecology' as fisheries related for this call? 3) Dept member here. @2: no. Like the ad says, fisheries are one area of interest, but not the only one. If we were only looking for a fisheries ecologist, the ad would've said that. 4) I'll apply. The blog post was very useful; it gave context to the state of the dept. Thanks for doing this.*3 5) Dept member here who spoke to someone on the search committee. There were roughly 100-150 applicants, split roughly evenly between Canadian and non-Canadian. 6) 100+ wow, that's encoraging, thanks for the infor 7) I guess fairly common for a university in a major city to receive this number of applicants. 8) Calgary prof here. This is more applications than we'd typically receive in this dept. Not sure why--could be many factors, or just happenstance.But yes, it's not rare for North American research unis in large cities to receive this many applicants: https://dynamicecology.wordpress.com/2019/03/04/heres-some-data-on-how-many-people-apply-for-n-american-tt-faculty-positions-in-ecology-and-allied-fields/ 9) Maybe  high number of applicants because almost every single other Canadian job on this board is a Canada Research Chair or Excellence Chair, which are geared for more for senior academics (Assoc Prof). Almost no Canadian Asst. Prof positions this year on the board. 10) As a Canadian ECR, I echo that - the CERC program has, in my opinion, been a disaster for Canadian ECRs. Universities are generally facing huge deficits across the board due to cutbacks on international student permits (a complex issue in Canada that drew heat due to astronomical rental/housing prices), so a government program pumping cash directly into hiring international bigwigs has basically made all universities defer hiring assisstant profs and take this money instead to make up staffing shortages due to retirement/attrition. Canadian ECRs got screwed this year, and while I can understand the strategy of the Carney government at a national scale I am massively resentful towards this. 11) Maybe take this discussion to the General Discussion or Venting tab, since the convo no longer has anything to do with this job specifically? 12) Invited for the short interview stage 26-Sept (x3) 13) Congrats! Can I ask what your general area/system is that you work on? 14) @ 10 I'm also disappointed that there haven't been any changes to the CRC2 (yet) under the current government, but it was the previous government that put the identity criteria on the CRCs. The CERCs are the real problems for "bigwigs", the CRCs are the ones that are discriminatory against Canadian ECRs. 15) @13 I do mostly fish ecology at the community level. 16) Did they already do in person interviews? 17) Anyone invited for in person interviews yet? 18) @16 probably no in person interviews just yet since remote ones were recent @17 not me at least 19) Nor me 20) Don't quote me on this, but rumors are that the committee skipped the zoom interview altogether and went directly to in-person; 21) Did a zoom interview and got the in-person interview invitation 10/29 22) Fuck, thought that short interview went really well, was really hopeful for this one. Congrats to those who got the interview. x3 23) Any update?

column10: This seems like the exact same search that was run last fall although that one says that an offer was accepted (it's still on this board way below). The language and title is almost identical. 1) Can confirm that offer was accepted OP) Thanks 1. So I guess this is just a second hire in the same area. x2 2) So many questions - if it's one more of the same exact position, wouldn't they want to hire who already interviewed last year? I wonder if it's worth to apply again, as I wasn't even selected for the interview step. @2) Almost always reapply. Different year, maybe different goals, maybe different folks on the SC. Someone in the crowd could be the one you need to know. @2 -- definitely reapply. I've seen people get ignored the first time and get interviews the second, or go to campus interview the first tiemn and not even move to short list the second time. It really depends on a bunch of factors, including luck. If you are interested in a position, always apply! OP) There are multiple anticipated retirements in the department, hence the multiple searches in recent years. Actually a really great time to apply since there have been two hires in the past two years, and this would be the third. 3) Yes, the previous offer was accepted and the selected candidate has already joined the department. Yes, this advertisement is similar to the one from last year. The goal is to conduct a broad search to continue to build the department and to replace recent and anticipated retirements. The administration only authorized a single position last year, so it is necessary to advertise again this year. All prior applicants and all others interested are encouraged to apply. 4) is anyone else having issues with Interfolio? It says 10 documents required, I have uploaded 10 (including 3 separate PDFs for each of my references' contact information), but it still says there is something missing. If I click on "additional documents" (only thing I don't have something uploaded to) it looks like the normal "recommendation" portal, but the emails it is populating do not include any information about Fordham. Seems like a really weird bug with the system (or me?!) - nevermind, fixed it!! :) [anonymous trash talk & rejoinder deleted -AP] 5) 10/21 Zoom interview invitation x4 6) What are your research areas - people who got the zoom interview? Curious since I thought I was a good fit. 7) @6- zoom interviewee here- behavioral ecologist - social behavior, mating systems, communication. 8) @7 Thanks! 9) I also got a zoom interview invite - behavioral/evolutionary ecologist - phylogenetics, speciation, sexual selection w/ inverts. 10) There were over 300 applicants for this position. 11) 10/30 on campus invite received x3 12) offer made?

column10: SC member here - this is a broad search. The SC is interested in reviewing applications from anyone with expertise in animal cognition, although we especially encourage applicants who study primate cognition or animal welfare to apply. Please note that salaries are due to increase significantly by the time the position begins: Assistant Professor salary ranges for this position are set to increase to $90,838-109,025 on 09/01/2025, and again to $94,017-112,841 on 09/01/2026. This position is planned to start in August, 2026 at the start of the Fall, 2026 semester. Hunter College is a wonderful place to work, with a diverse, passionate student body of CUNY students. TT faculty have an opportunity to mentor undergraduates, MA students in the Animal Behavior and Conservation Program, and PhD students in Psychology at the Graduate Center, CUNY.  2. Anyone know the teaching/research expectation? Any updates (as of 10/31)? On New Psych Job Wiki someone said they received a zoom invite 10/14 (https://sites.google.com/view/psychjobwiki2425/tenure-track-positions?authuser=0)

column10: 1) Is the pay livable for this area? 2) Livable but you'll be renting and it would be helpful to have a spouse's salary 3) note requirement about statment of faith 4) What do you consider livable? Is $90K+ for 9 months not a livable wage? 5) according to Payscale.com, cost of living in Malibu is 187% higher than the national average, including housing that is 645% higher than the national average. Median home price is $3,225,692. So, there's that. Of course, you could live in a surrounding area, but it's not like anything in that region is affordable. 6) Probably a silly question, but if I am not involved in a community of faith, is that an automatic dealbreaker? 7) @6 no, they cannot legally discriminate based on religion, though weird get around where they can give some sort of preference to people with shared faith. in practicality you do not want to work at a place like Pepperdine unless you are christian, it would be very isolating 7) @ 4, it's all relative, comparing 90k in that area to my current area would be like make 26k, which I do not classify as livable. 8) Some schools have programs to help new faculty find housing or provide on-campus. Quick search on PU found this: https://www.pepperdine.edu/reo/employee-housing/ Read for details, it still may not be a good deal. 9) @5, if nothing in the region is affordable, then how could faculty (and staff who earn less) work and live there? Pepperdine has affordable employe housing in Malibu and the surrounding neighborhoods are affordable: Santa Monica, Oxnard, Calabasas, Agoura Hills, Thousand Oaks, etc. 10) @7, yes, faith-based universities in the United States can legally discriminate in hiring on the basis of religion. Don't apply if you're not a Christian. 11) as a heads up When I applied in 2020, Pepperdine had a statement of faith on the last screen before submitting that was fairly specific and I was not comfortable signing (as a Christian who has submitted a statement of faith to other institutions).  I felt bad about asking for letters but ultimately didn't apply.  Would probably be worth looking into before putting the time into an application for 12) I feel like I have seen (and not applied) to this job for a couple (a few) years in a row. Anyone know what the deal is? 13) SC here. Feel free to contact me if you are a prospective applicant and want to discuss the position before submitting an application. 14) @11, was it a declaration of "accepting jesus christ as your lord and savior" or was it more intense than that? That's all I can find from googling. 15) @9, subsidized housing aside, to answer your Q: a.) they don't live comfortably, b.) they come from a relatively well-off family, c.) they have a spouse that makes more, and/or d.) like you mentioned, they're ok with a longish commute (though it's a stretch to call some of those surrounding areas you listed "affordable").  16) I just went through the application process. Pepperdine does NOT have a statement of faith on the last screen before submitting. 17) Any news? Also, did they change their job ad to be LESS research oriented? (i.e. no longer ask for research statement?) 18) They're asking for research statement and letters of rec from those they want to interview. 19) Any news after zoom?

column10: 1) Says job will take place at "University of Toronto Mississauga: Biology" but that "UTM is part of the tri-campus University of Toronto ecosystem, and all faculty have appointments in the graduate departments of Cell and Systems Biology, or Ecology and Evolutionary Biology.". Does that mean once can choose to be permanenlty situated in the EEB dept? Missisauga and Toronto are two very different things 2) EEB alumnus here, probably not. You will likely be based at UTM and involved in tri-campus service, like sitting on student committees. 3) Note: "This position is an excellent opportunity for individuals working on any organism that does not require the use of animal care facilities" 4)@1, could you expand on the difference between UTM and U of T? 5) U of T is the main, St. George campus downtown in Toronto. UTM is the satellite campus in Mississauga (which is part of the GTA but west of the the downtown). Because Toronto is the worst city in the world, they are about 30 km apart but it takes an hour to drive between them. 6) An hour in good traffic :)  7) UTM has a nice campus and Mississauga is very family-friendly 8) Echoing 7) here. Mississauga is very green and the campus sits on Erindale Park and the Credit River. If you live near a GO train station then it takes no time to get to downtown Toronto. Alternatively, several faculty live in west end Toronto and commute. Salary and start-up are the same across campuses and you're very much a member of the EEB and CSB groups. 9) I grew up in Mississauga - the campus is in a nice place and very family friendly. You can get a pretty decent startup if you advocate for yourself. 10) The ad is a bit sparse on details for statement length etc. Is it reasonable to assume a 3-4 page research statement, 1 page teaching statement ish? 10) Teaching load? 11) No specific guidelines were offered for page limits. I would assume the following for those making last minute submissions: 1-2 pg cover letter, 2-pg research statement, 1-pg diversity statement, and a teaching dossier (good luck if you've never created one; Dalhousie has guidelines on how to create one and it is not overly burdensome).12)Any updates on this? 13) @12 my dear comrade, it closed less than 24 hours ago! But I get your enthusiasm lol 14)Any updates? 15) None here as of 11/12 x13 15) No updates as of 01/12, anyone else? x11 16) Wild speculation, but it wouldn't surprise me if they're waiting until the Dept Chair returns from leave in January to schedule interviews. I don't think this place does zoom screening. 17) Is no zoom screening a Canadian thing? UdeMontreal just jumped straight to on-campus invites too as far as I can tell 16 again) Probably, the only Canadian university I know that does zoom interviews is UBC. There may be more but it seems to be uncommon. 18) I've had zoom interviews at two canadian unis and straight to on-campus at two, so it seems like a mixed bag, depending on seach committee etc. 19) Zoom interview offered 12/8 20) congratulations @ 19 give'm hell x5 21) in the zoom interview the SC mentioned the in-person interviewees would be notified in early January- anyone have any updates? 22) @21 I was told the same - no word from them yet x2 23) Looks like my application is closed on the portal (Jan 16) so I'm probably out. Anyone receive an onsite invite yet? 24) Nope (Jan 16) x2 25) 23 again- just received an invitation for an in-person interview 26) @23 yoooooo congrats!!!! x2

I am one of the zoom folks - high teaching experience (combined 14 semesters of instructor of record / TA) but a relatively weak pub record (~10 pubs), but I will ad that my package didn't get me a zoom at Villanova - I get the vibe this department is very teaching-focused department and that maybe they care more about teaching experience and training than publication rate. My area of focus is eco/evo/devo in a non-model insect group. 13) @10 I got this too, (and yes, love this from them, instead of ghosting) does this mean like a waitlist for zoom?. 14) @12) May I also ask what career stage you are, e.g., new or more senior postdoc? @12) I am senior postdoc, starting 3rd year of 2nd postdoc, 5th year in total of postdocing 15) Zoom invitee- conservation ecology, ~10 pubs, 8 semesters TAing, starting 3rd yr total of postdocing, 2 postdocs. Often these stupid requirements (50 pubs??) come out when they have someone in mind. 3) haha what a joke! x8 4) jesus, what early career reseacher has 50 publications? 5) I'm like 1% eligible for this position lol 6) I've got about 45, but I'm marginally ECR and I don't have a job either. 7) Eh, I qualify easily and don't have a permanent job and I know several others in the same position. Unfortunately I'm geographically constrained. Strict number limits are obviously dumb, but it's way more common in searches I've seen to hire underqualified than overqualified candidates, so I guess that won't happen in this case. 8) Also, if it is an internal candidate with 50 pubs who needs a permanent job, they should absolutely hire that person anyway! x2 9) @ 4, 8 I have >60 and am still in the ECR bracket without a TT job. There's been a lot of targeted discrimination in academic hiring over the last decade - as 7 points out there's often no way to justify the hires objectively. It's actually nice to see standards here for a change. 8) It says 50 publications which is unreasonable OR 500 citations, which is not hard. Come on, people, learn how to read. Portuguese universities are very inbred and they need these type of calls to remove internal candidates which have managed contract after contract despite accomplishing very little. It is a not the best strategy in the long term, but it is meant to address these cases of inbreeding and "old wood" that is not that old.  9) I think these stats ae basically being very open to applicants that they want definitive productivity demonstrated.  I know MANY people who exceed all of these metrics before exiting a postdoc.  However, MOST people would not hit these numbers until at least a couple of years into an assistant professor position.  The largest majority of people in higher education actually never reach these numbers, ahving been trapped in teaching sweaat shops for too long. 10) the only way a person pre postdoc would meet any of these citation or publication metrics is by being a part of a well known and productive lab in which they were a co-author on every publication put out during their PhD whether they did any work on that project or not. This kind of thing incentivizes and necessitates gratuitous co-authorships. Also @(8) 500 citations is "easy"?? again what early career academic at the postdoc level has 500 citations without being co-author on dozens of papers they had little to no part of, and only in fields that have really high citation metrics. In a lot of ecology you are lucky to get 50 citations with 10 papers if your field is niche. 11) I won't argue whether the metric is a good idea or not 10, but there are tons of postdoc/research associate ecologists who don't have permanent positions yet and have way more than 500 citations.

column10: Brazilian here. Great university, one of the best in Latin America. São Paulo has a lot of money for research. Salary is good. But before anyone gets excited, I suggest you investigate the hiring process in Brazil: which insluded writen exams (taken in portuguese IN SÃO PAULO!). Another Brazilian here. Some processes offer the possibility to do the test in English. To be honest, it's a bogus system - they use these tests because they're too lazy to properly review every applicant's CV and research record. Yes, the exam is required by law, but universities are too lazy to confront this requirement and design a more effective process that actually evaluates research merit. At the end, you read your test to the professors evaluating you, and they throw scores as they please to pass the candidates they want - increasing the score here and there for the ones they favor, decreasing for others. Bottom line: after the whole process that involves a 5-hour long test, a mock lecture, an interview... the committee president tries to convince the other members to pick the candidate he wants. The selection is subjective like all selections are, but they include this long test only to make things worse. @Brazilians: just to clarify - fluency in portguese is required to pass this exam? Im in the same institute, different department. English is in principle not required for the exam, but you do need to have your PhD diploma validaded by the university BEFORE the application date, so this should be started immediatelly. There are instructions in the full job posting. I should add that the desire to hire more broadly is sincere, but would be against the norm. There is a Canadian in the department (Taran Grant) that could be contacted for an honest assessment of your chances.

column10: Any idea what the teaching load is like here? 2) Department member here: Teaching load is currently a 3/2, but the college is moving to a 2/2 in the next few years. Under the 3/2 model, there is a course reduction for the first year. It’s important to note that class sizes are small, and upper-level labs (200 and 300-level) count as a full course, meaning a lecture and its associated lab together count as two courses. Also, the only course with multiple lab sections is Introductory Biology, and those labs are taught by dedicated faculty members. 3) Note that letters of rec are required up front and before the review date 4) It looks like the letters are due on 9/15, is that not correct? 3 again) I just meant before the review date so you can have your entire application in by 9/15 5) It looks like the interfolio site has a feature that lets you request letters from your references so they have the option to upload letters themselves. 6) Can we submit the application on Interfolio before the letters are uploaded, or do we need to wait for the letters to show up? 5) again- @6- I was able to submit my application without the letters. 7) Search committee member here: please submit your application without waiting for your references to upload their letters. 8) "research program that includes a field or laboratory component" - does this mean there is not much point applying as a theory/modeling researcher? 9) Any updates? 10) nope! x7 11) Zoom invitation 9/29 x6 12) congrats all! can I please ask what career stage, how many pubs, area of expertise to those who got interviews? Anything along the lines of what you think helped your CV for this search would be really helpful to those of us who didn't get an interview  : ( 12) insect ecology broadly (second-year postdoc; 2 years of teaching experience as a TA + one semester as instructor of record; 17 pubs). I hope this is helpful. 13) They want a list of essential equipment provided at the zoom interview stage! I've never seen that before (even prior to campus interview is rare). x2 14) this is not uncommon for PUIs because they want to make sure they can actually provide the facilities/resources you need to be successful. If you are going to require a greenhouse and they don't have one/don't have space to create one, that is going to hinder your work. Don't be too stressed about the request! 15) I've zoom interviewed at a bunch of PUIs and it aboslutely is rare. The problem isn't the stress, its extra time and work. 16) did anyone who did a Zoom ask about timeline to on-campus interview decision? 17) no, but I imagine invites will go out in the next week 18) campus interview invitation 10/10 x2 19) congrats everyone, it looks like an amazing opportunity! 20) for those that were not invited to campus, did anyone hear anything more from the college? 21) Nope x4 22) Any updates from anyone? 23) Not yet. 24) On-campus interview invite received Oct 10, with interview dates offered ranging Oct 23-Nov 4; 25) 11/24- got my rejection letter today (did not receive zoom interview) x4 same except did receieve zoom x2 26) have any on campus interviewers heard back yet? column10: "molecular and cellular biology" + no mention of ecology or evolution = not ecoevojob [discussion on relevance deleted -AP] 2) Hi! I posted this and am loosely involved in the search and work in the dept. I'm an eco person myself, and know a lot of eco/evo people who do genetics that could easily handle an intro class and have interesting upper-levels to share at the cell/molec scale that are not biomedical. Honestly, I'd be happy to see more applicants that span topics beyond biomed applications (yeast evolution! disease pathways in non-model systems, etc). That said, I am not chairing the search, but wanted the job ad to be widely viewed in a space like this because not all people who work in genetics are coming out of MCB PhD/post-docs. ALSO, to address the upper-level classes, I would think preference is towards classes that touch on molec/cell, but for instance, that could still be in eco/evo world too - for instance, we have a biogeographer/entomologist, but not a population geneticist, etc etc. 3) @2 Are you open to bacteria people who do genetics? 4) I think if you can teach courses related to genetics you are a good fit to be an applicant. The species/model of interest is secondary to the ability to teach genetics. Please refer to job ad for detail! 5) any news? 6) Job ad says "candidates should be prepared to provide three letters of reference by October 1, 2025, if requested". Given that, folks should hear back this week. maybe? 7) True, but the letter requests were already made during the application, right? 8) @7, 6 here: During the application, they requested the contact information of the reference. It seems that they requested letters yesterday because I was notified by academicJobsOnline.org that one of my references uploded the letter. Must admit though that I am confused if we were supposed to initiate the request by clicking that green arrow? Any thoughts? 9) I used interfolio emails for my ref letters and they were requested/uploaded when I submitted the application on 9/15. 10) so how do we know if our applications have made the initial cut? 9) no idea, just crossing my fingers for a zoom invite in the next week or two. 11) @8 I clicked on those arrows and put in the letters at the same time as I was submitting the applicaiton. Fingers crossed for next week. 12) I didn't click those green arrows. But they have requested letters from my references yesterday, which means I am not out of it yet. 13) @12, you got an email from them requesting letters? I am confused--I never clicked the green arrows but I assume if I didn't get a request, I'm out. 14) @13 My letter writers got email request to submit reference letters. I don't know if I was supposed to send/arrange these letter at the time of application, but I am hoping that I am still in the pool. I think, my opinian only, if candidates have already attached letters from, say interfolio (see above), at the time of application then they are still in the pool because there is no way to know if someone is out or in. Only way to find that out is to get email notifications for Zoom. 13) My letter writers did not receive requests for letters and I did not click the arrow to request these. I am presuming I shouldn't request AJO to send them notifications and that I would hear directly from Macalester if I needed to submit them. 14) This makes sense, next week or two will make it clear. 9) wish I hadn't used interfolio so I would know if I'm still in the running! x3. 15) Any Zoom interview invitations?  15) It does seem like you were supposed to request the letters directly through academicjobsonline if that's the platform you used per clicking the "?" icon next to reference letters on the job ad. 16) I did not request letters myself, but my writers were contacted last week 15) seems like the instructions were wrong then. Good luck to all of us! 9) Zoom interview invite received 10/3 x4 9) Onsite invite recieved 10/21 10) when? 9) Dates offered early-mid November 9) Offer made to another (via future PI slack) 11) official rejection letter 12) they hired a microbiologist, btw.

column10: "ORGANISMAL ECOLOGISTS whose research has a significant field component and who uses quantitative and/or computational modeling approaches to answer critical questions in ecology" 1) Anybody know who the search chair is? I am interested but don't know what exactly they are looking for with this combo of skills. 2) The wording was a little funny in the listing. Would the lab just be for Masters or PhDs too? I thought Villanova was a R2 school 3) Villanova's bio department has a terminal master's program but not a PhD program. 4) "For finalists, an official graduate transcript will be required and a reflection on the Mission of the University." How deeply is this reflection tied to the religious affiliation of the school? Any concept on the strength of religious befliefs in teaching and culture? 5) @4 FWIW: I was a grad student there in the late aughts and at least at that time, there was no strong connection between religious belief and teaching or research. Heck, the science building is Mendel Hall, as in the Augustinian monk and "father" of genetics Gregor Mendel. From my perspective, there was a deep respect for science and little, if any, direct connection (really none at all from my perspective) between religion and the functioning of the department. 6) I also was a grad student there around 10 years ago and I can second what 5 is saying. That said, I think a lot of the student body identifies as Catholic and there are crucifixes in every room lol 7) Went here as an undergrad (many years ago now) and it never felt like a "religious" school. Theology, ethics, and philosophy are required classes for all students, but weren't exclusively catholic. Biology classes were just as secular as non-religious schools. Honestly, fewer anti-abortion protestors on campus compared to the public R1 I attended for grad school. 8) I am confused about the definition of organismal ecologists--is this wording used to specifically exclude population and community elements to the study of organisms? confused because of the juxtaposition of organismal ecology with quantitative/computational components... 9) note that in the listing it says review starts Sept 2 but closing date is Sept 5; 10) SC member here: Answering a few questions: The job ad is specifically broad as we want to find the best candidate for our department. We are looking for someone who can combine ecological/computational expertise - organismal does not exclude pop or community but more focuses on multicellular organisms/communities. We are an R2 with a terminal master's in Biology. We will begin reviewing applications on Sept 2nd. VU while a catholic school does not dictate what we teach or how we run our classrooms/research labs. The reflection on the mission does not need to be religiously focused and should rather highlight how you can move the mission of the university forward with your teaching and research program. 11) That's super helpful 10, thank you! x3 12) just a heads up there are not separate places to upload the undergrad and grad transcripts. Mine were two separate docs so if you are in the same shoes you either need to merge the docs or figure out another place to stick one of the transcipt documents - I put mine in the "optional response to mission statement" section, hopefully the SC gets it. 13) Zoom interview invitation received 09/14. x3 14) wow that was a fast turnaround congrats @ 13 et al. 14) Feeling pretty bummed about not reaching the zoom interview stage for this one--would love to know what types of CVs got to that stage. X7 15) @14 what type of information are you looking for? 16) Not 14, but I'm curious about taxa/level of study. I also thought I was a great fit. Oh well. 17) @16 insect ecology w/ a focus on native pollinators/population ecology. 18) @16 behavioral ecology with focus on fitness and life history consequences of behavioral plasticity in rodents (edit @19: 6th year postdoc, 17 publications). 19) Follow up to 14: curious about general things like career stage (assist. prof, 2nd year postdoc, 6th year postdoc), publications (how many), etc. That type of info would be very helpful for better understanding why we weren't considered and could help us with our packages in the future. Thanks in advance. x2 20) Try not to get too down if you didn't get a zoom - I have been really competitive making it to at least zoom interviews for PUI type jobs and I didn't get one either, it seems like this cycle is extra competitive and folks with R1 type publication records are in the ring too. Remember there is so much stochasticity in hiring and you probably have a package that will be competitive elsehwere. you got this! 21) on-campus interview request 10/6 x2 22) offer received 12/8 22) offer officially accepted 1/21

column10: $64,000 to $70,000. Teach 24-contact hours each academic year. One course with a lab is typically 7-contact hours. column10: 1) That's an extremely broad subject area 2) Shoot, I work on Moose Hoof Disease. Maybe next year.  3) Surely this is targeted job for a specific person, right?  There can't be more than 1 or 2 elk hoof disease researchers in the world... 4) I specialize in Elf Hook Disease. Can't hurt to still apply right? 5) brutal for folks specializing on Elk Ankle Disease. So close 5) It is amazing how some eco/evo biologists don't realize how much bigger applied fields like vet science and ag science are than our little corner of the ivory tower. A bunch of Depts. of Natural Resources in Western states have entire programs to track and manage elk hoof disease... x2. 6) SCM - not targeted for a specific person; here's a BRIEF DESCRIPTION – Washington State University’s College of Veterinary Medicine seeks a full-time (12 month) tenure-track Associate or Full Professor in the Department of Veterinary Microbiology and Pathology (VMP) to focus on elk hoof disease as part of a program studying infectious diseases of wildlife and diseases that occur at the wildlife-domestic animal interface. Since 2017, WSU has led research into elk hoof disease since the Washington State Legislature provided generous operating funding and a mandate to monitor and assess causes of and potential solutions for the disease. More information on WSU’s research and outreach on elk hoof disease is available at: https://vetmed.wsu.edu/departments/veterinary-microbiology-and-pathology/elk-hoof-disease/ - @5 just let us make jokes from our little corner of the ivory tower we have so little joy left x2 7) There's an epidemic of overly-tailored job ads. It really puts me on the back foot. 8) @7 hopefully your back foot does not get elk hoof disease; 9) SCM here - just to keep you all on your 'toes' (hooves?), the review date has been updated to August 17, 2025. Can the spreadsheet owner help us update the review date?  AP) @9 updated!

(1) there are two separate positions. 3) Any updates? 4) Not that I know of x 7 5) Just got an email saying that based on current H1B situation they will not be sponsoring H1B visas, so I assume that means they will not be shortlisting H1B-dependent candidates. 6) Also received a similar email about not sponsoring H1B visas. x7 7) Maybe this is our first test as applicants--sending a confusing email (or at least one that doesn't apply to every recipient) to see if we're up to the task of responding for clarification? 8) i had two other schools this cycle send v similar emails so not surprised and don't think they're expecting any response 9) I did email to ask whether this means they are removing non-US applicants from consideration and they clarified that this is not the case - it was simply a general information email. Apparently they have no way of knowing what the specific visa needs of any applicant are so it'll be on a case-by-case basis. 10) Any news? eg. zoom invites? 11) Nov 25 zoom invite x5 12) Is everyone who got a zoom systems bio? 13) not particularly - I do microbial (functional/ecological) genomics. I guess that's the other search one line below. 14) Isn't this the same job anyway? I don't think these are separate tracks (+1 for functional genetics) 15) Update from search committee - these are indeed separate tracks.
